DIV1.P:
NO
WIT
HELP LIKE A VVOMANS.
A COMEDY, BY Tho, Middleton, Gent.
LONDON: Printed for Humphrey Moseley, at the Prince's Arms in St. Pauls Church∣yard. 1657.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: So many Ears, so many Eyes?
Some in wit, some in shows
Take delight, and some in Clothes;
Some for mirth they chiefly come,
Some for passion, for both some;
Some for lascivious meetings, that's their arrant;
Some to detract, and ignorance their warrant.
Opinion tos'd in such wilde Seas!
Yet I doubt not, if Attention
You below, to take things quickly,
We shall both make you sad, and tickle ye,

LIST.ITEM: SIr Oliver Twilight, a rich old Knight.
Philip his Son, servant to Mistress Grace.
Sandfield, friend to Philip, servant to Mistress Jane.
Mr. Sunset, true Father of Mistress Grace.
Mr. Beveril, Brother to Mistress Low-water:
Lady Golden fleece, a rich Widow.
Mistress Grace, Sunsets Daughter, but supposed Twi∣lights.
Mistress Jane, Twilights Daughter, but supposed Sunsets:

DIV1.HEAD:
NO
Wit
Help
Like a WOMANS.

DIV3.HEAD: Scaen 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Philip, Sir Oliver Twilights Son, with Savor∣wit his Fathers man.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I Am at my wits ends Savor-wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Savorw.
SP.P: And I am evn follow∣ing after you as fast as I can Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My wife will be forc'd from me; my plea∣sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Talk no more on't Sir; how can there be any hope i'th' middle, when w'are both at our wits end in the beginning? My invention was nev'r so gra∣vel'd since I first set out upon't.

LG.L: Nor does my stop stick onely in this wheel▪
Though it be a main vexation, but I'm grated
In a dear absolute Friend, yong Mr. Sandfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: I there's another rub too.

LG.L: Who supposes
That I make love to his affected Mistress,
When 'tis my Father works against the peace
Of both our spirits, and woes unknown to me▪
He strikes out sparks of undeserved anger,
'Bwixt old Steel friendship, and new Stony hate:
As much forgetful of the merry hours,
The circuits of our youth hath spent and worn,
As if they had not been, or we not born.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: See where he comes.

LG.L: Unmerciful in torment!
Will this disease never forsake mine eye?
It must be kil'd first, if it grow so painful;
Work it out strongly at one time, that th'anguish
May never more come near thy precious sight.
If my eternal sleep will give thee rest,
Close up mine eyes with opening of my Brest.
I feel thy wrongs at midnight, and the weight
Of thy close Treacheries: Thou hast a friendship
As dangerous as a Strumpets, that will kiss
Men into poverty, distress, and ruine.
And to make clear the face of thy foul deeds,
Thou work'st by Seconds.
Then may the sharp point of an inward horror
Strike me to earth, and save thy weapon guiltless.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Not in thy Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: How much is truth abus'd, when 'tis kept silent!

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: O defend me Friendship!

LG.L: True; your anger's in an error all this while, Sir;
But that a Lovers weapon now hears reason,
'Tis out still like a mad mans; hear but me Sir.
'Ts my yong Masters injury, not yours,
That you quarrel with him for; and this shows
As if y'would challenge a lame man the field,
And cut off's head, because he has lost his Legs.
His grief makes him dead flesh, as it appear'd
By offring up his Brest to you; for believe it Sir,
Had he not greater crosses of his own,
Your Hilts could not cross him—

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: How?

LG.L: Not your Hilts Sir.
Come I must have you friends, a pox of weapons▪
There's a Whore gapes for't; put it up i'th' Scab∣bard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Thou'rt a made slave.

LG.L: Come, give me both your hands,
Y'are in a Quagmire both; should I release you now,
Your wits would both come home in a stinking pickle;
Your Fathers old Nose would smell you out present∣ly.
Tell him the Secret, which no mortal knows
But thou and I, and then he will confess
How much he wrong'd the patience of his Friend.
Then thus the Marigold opens at the splendor
Of a hot constant friendship 'twixt you both:
'Tis not unknown to your ear, some ten years since,
My Mistress his good Mother, with a Daughter
About the age of six, crossing to Jernsey,
Was taken by the Dunkirks, sold both, and separated,
As the last news brings hot, the first and last
So much discover'd; for in nine years space
No certain tidings of their life or death,
Or what place held 'em, Earth, the Sea, or Heaven,
Came to the old mans ears, the Knight my Master,
Till about five moneths since, a Letter came,
Sent from the Mother, which related all
Their taking, selling, separation,
And never meeting; and withal required
Six hundred Crowne for Ransom, which my old Ma∣ster
No sooner heard the sound, but told the sum,
Gave him the Gold, and sent us both aboard;
We landing by the way, having a care
To lighten us of our carriage, because Gold
Is such a heavy mettal, eas'd our Pockets
In Wenches Aprons; Women were made to bear,
But for us Gentlemen 'tis most unkindly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: A pure Rogue still!

LG.L: Amongst the rest Sir
'Twas my yong Masters chance there to dote finely
Upon a sweet yong Gentlewoman; but one
That would not sell her honor for the Indies,
Till a Priest struck the bargain, and then half a crown dispatcht it.
To be brief, Wedded her and bedded her,
Brought her home hither to his Fathers house;
And with a fair tale of mine own bringing up,
She passes for his sister that was sold.
Let me not lose my self in wondring at thee;
But how made you your score even for the Mother?
Pish, easily, we told him how her Fortunes
Mockt us, as they mockt her; when we were o'th' Sea,
She was o'th' Land; and as report was given,
When we were landed, she was gone to Heaven;
So he believes two lyes one error bred,
The Daughter ransom'd, and the Mother dead.
Let me admire thee, and withal confess
My injuries to friendship.
They're all pardon'd:
These are the arms I bore against my friend—
But what's all this to th'present? this dis∣course
Leaves you i'th' Bogg still.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: On good Savorwit.

LG.L: For yet our policy has croft our selves;
For the old Knave my Master, little thinking her
Wife to his Son, but his own daughter still,
Seeks out a match for her.
Here I feel the Surgeon
At second dressing
And h'as entertain'd
Ev'n for pure need, for fear the Glass should crack
That is already broken, but well soader'd,
A meer Sot for her Suiter, a rank Fox;
One weatherwise, that woes by the Almanack,
Observes the Full and Change; an arrant Moon-Calf.
And yet because the Fool demands no portion
But the bare Down of her Smock, the old fellow
Worne to the bone with a dry courteous Itch,
To save his purse, and yet bestow his childe,
Consents to waste lumps of Almanack stuff
Kned with May Butter.——Now as I have thought on't,
I'll spoil him in the baking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Prethee, as how Sirrah?

LG.L: I'll give him such a crack in one o'th' sides,
He shall quite run out of my Masters favor▪

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I should but too much love thee for that—

LG.L: Thus then; to help you both at once, and so good night to you.
After my wit has shipt away the fool,
As he shall part, I'll buz into the ear
Of my old Master, that you Sir, Master Sandfield,
Deerly affect his Daughter, and will take her
With little or no portion; well stood out in't.
Methinks I see him caper at that news,
And in the full cry, Oh! This brought about
And wittily dissembled on both parts;
You to affect his love he to love yours;
I'll so beguile the Father at the marriage,
That each shall have his own, and both being wel∣com'd,
And chamber'd in one house; as 'tis his pride
To have his Childrens children got successively
On his Fore-fathers Feather beds, in the day time's
To please the old mans eye sight, you may dally,
And set a kiss on the wrong Lip, no sin in't.
Brothers and sisters do't, Cousins do more:
But pray take heed you be not kin to them,
So in the night time, nothing can deceive you,
Let each know his own work, and there I leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Let me applaud thee.

LG.L: Blest be all thy ends,
That mak'st arm'd enemies, embracing friends.
About it speedily.
I need no pricking;
I'm of that mettle, so well pac'd, and free,
There's no good riders that use spur to me.
Oh! are you come?

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: Are any comforts coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: I never go without 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: Thou sport'st joys, that utterance cannot perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Hark, are they risen!

LG.L: Yes, long before I left 'em,
And all intend to bring the Widow homeward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.

LG.L: Depart then Mistress to avoid suspect,
Our good shall arive time enough at your heart:
Poor fools that ever more take a green Surfet
Of the first-fruits of joys—Let a man but shake the Tree,
How soon they'll hold up their laps to receive com∣fort!
The musick that I struck, made her soul dance; Peace—

SP.STAGE: Enter the Lady Widow Golden-fleece with Sir Gil∣bert Lambston, Mr. Pepperton, Mr. Overdon, suiters; after them the two old men, Sir Oliver Twilight, and Mr. Sunset, with their Daughters, Grace Twilight, Jane Sunset.

LG.L: Here comes the Lady Widow, the late wife
To the deceas'd Sir Avarice Golden-fleece,
Second to none for Usury and Extortion,
As too well it appears on a poor Gentleman,
One Mr. Low-water, from whose estate
He pull'd that Fleece, that makes his Widow weight;
Those are her Suiters now, Sir Gilbert Lambston, Mr. Pepperton, Mr. Overdon.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Nay good Sir Oliver Twilight, Mr. Sunset, We'll trouble you no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: Sir Oliv. No trouble sweet Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lamb.
SP.P: We'll see the Widow at home, it shall be our charge that.

LG.L: It shall be so indeed; Thanks good Sir Oli∣ver, and to you both,
I am indebted for those curtesies
That will ask me a long time to requite.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliver.
SP.P: Ah, 'tis but your pleasant condition to give it out so Madam!

LG.L: Mistress Grace and Mistress Jane, I wish you both
A fair contented Fortune in your choices,
And that you happen right.
Thanks to you good Madam:
There's more in that word right then you imagine.
I now repent, Girls, a rash oath I took
When you were both Infants, to conceal a Secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace
SP.P: What do'st concern good Madam?

LG.L: No, no; since you are both so well, 'tis well enough;
It must not be reveal'd; 'tis now no more
Then like mistaking of one hand for t'other.
A happy time to you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: The like to you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: I shall long much to have this Riddle open'd?

LG.L: I would you were so kinde to my poor Kinswoman,
And the distressed Gentleman her husband,
Poor Mr. Low-water, who on Ruine leans;
You keep this Secret, as you keep his means▪
Thanks good Sir Oliver Twilight,
Welcome sweet Mr. Pepperton,
Mr. Overdon, welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: And, goes the business well 'twixt those yong lovers?

LG.L: Betwixt your son and Mr. Sunset's daugh∣ter
The Line goes even Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Good Lad, I like thee.

LG.L: But Sir, there's no proportion, height, or evenness
Betwixt that Equinoctial and your Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: 'Tis true, and I'm right glad on't▪

LG.L: Are you glad Sir?
There's no proportion in't.
I marry am I Sir▪
I can abide no word that ends in Portion;
I'll give her nothing.
Say you should not Sir,
As I'll ne'r urge your worship 'gainst your nature;
Is there no Gentleman think you, of worth and cre∣dit,
Will open's Bed to warm a naked Maid?
A hundred gallant fellows, and be glad
To be so set a work: Virginity
Is no such cheap Ware, as you make account on,
That it had need with portion be set off;
For that sets off a portion in these days.
Play on, sweet Boy; O I could hear this musick all day long▪
When there's no money to be parted from! strike on, good Lad.
Do not wise men and great, often bestow
Ten thousand pound in Jewels that lye by 'em?
If so, what Jewel can lye by a man
More pretious then a Virgin? if none more preti∣ous,
Why should the Pillow of a fool be grac'd
With that brave Spirits with dearness have imb ac'd?
And then perhaps ere the third Spring come on,
Sends home your Diamond crack't, the beauty gone.
And more to know her, 'cause you shall not doubt her,
A number of poor Sparks twinckling about her:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Now thou play'st Dowlands Lachrymae to thy Master.

LG.L: But shall I dry your eyes with a merry Jigg now,
And make you look like Sun-shine in a showre?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: How, how, my honest Boy, sweet Sa∣vorwit!

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Yong Mr: Sandfield, gallant Mr. Sandfield,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Ha what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Affects your daughter strangely.

LG.L: Brave Mr. Sandfield! let me hug thy zeal
Unto thy Masters house; Hah Mr. Sandfield!
But he'll expect a portion.
Not a whit Sir,
As you may use the matter.
Nay, and the matter fall into my using
The Devil a penny that he gets of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: He lyes at the mercy of your Lock and Key Sir; you may use him as you lit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Say'st thou me so? is he so far in do∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Quite over head and ears Sir; nay more, he means to run mad, and break his Neck off some high Steeple, if he have her not:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Now bless the yong Gentlemans Gri∣stles; I hope to be a Grand-father yet by 'em.

LG.L: That may you Sir, to marry a chopping Girl with a plump Buttock,
Will hoist a Fartingal at five years old,
And call a man between eleven and twelve
To take part of a peece of Mutton with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Ha pretious Wag! hook him in finely, do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Make clear the way for him first, set the Gull going.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: An Ass, an Ass, I'll quickly dash his woo∣ing.

LG.L: Why now the clocks go right again; it must be a strange wit
That makes the wheels of youth and age so hit;
The one are dry, worn, rusty, fur'd, and soil'd;
Loves wheels are glib, ever kept clean, and oyl'd.
I cannot chuse but think of this good Fortune,
That gallant Mr. Sandfield!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Stay, stay, stay!
What comfort gives my Almanack to day?

Luck I beseech thee, good days, evil days, June, July; Speak a good word for me now, and I have her; let me see, the fifth day 'twixt Hawk and Buzzard; the sixth day backward and forward; that was beastly to me, I remember; the seventh day on a slippery pin; the eight day fire and towe; the nineth day, the Market is mar'd, that's long of the Hucksters I war∣rant you; but now the tenth day, luck I beseech thee now, before I look into't; the eleventh day, against the hair; a Pox on't, would that hair had been left out; against the hair! that hair will go nigh to choak me; had it been against any thing but that, 'twould not have troubled me, because it lyes cross i'th' way. Well, I'll try the fortune of a good face yet, though my Almanack leave me i'th' Sands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Such a match too, I could not wish a better!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Mass, here he walks! Save you sweet Sir Oliver,—Sir Oliver Twilight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Oh pray come to me a quarter of a year hence; I have a little business now.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: How a quarter of a year hence? what shall I come to you in September?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Nor in November neither, good my Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P:
Y'are not a mad Knight; you will not let your daughter hang past August, will you? she'll drop down under Tree then: She's no Winter fruit
I assure you, if you think to put her in crust after Christmas?

LG.L: Sir, in a word, depart; my Girl's not for you,
I gave you a drowsie promise in a dream,
But broad awake now, I call't in again.
Have me commended to your wit, farewel Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Now the Devil run away with you, and some louzy Fidler with your daughter: May Clarken∣well have the first cut of her, and Hounds-ditch pick the Bones. I'll never leave the love of an open heart∣ed Widow, for a narrow-ey'd Maid again; go out of the road way like an Ass, to leap over Hedge and Ditch; I'll fall into the beaten path again, and invite the Widow home to a Banquet; let who lift seek out new ways, I'll be at my journeys end before him; My Almanack told me true, how I should fare, Let no man think to speed against the hair.

LG.L: Is there no Saving-means? no help Religious
For a distressed Gentlewoman to live by?
Has Virtue no Revenue? who has all then?
Is the worlds lease from Hell, the Devils Head-land∣lord?
Oh how was Conscience the right Heir put by?
Law would not do such an unrighteous deed,
Though with the fall of Angels t'had been feed.
Where are our hopes in banks? was honesty
A yonger sister, without portion left,
No dowry in the Chamber, beside wantonness?
O miserable Orphan! 'twixt two extreams runs there no blessed Mean,
No comfortable strain that I may kiss it?
Must I to whoredom, or to beggery lean,
My minde being sound? is there no way to miss it?
Is't not injustice, that a Widow laughs
And lays her mourning part upon a wife?
That she should have the garment, I the heart;
My wealth her Uncle left her, and me her grief.
Yet stood all miseries in their loathed'st forms
On this hand of me, thick like a fowl mist,
And here the bright enticements of the world,
In clearest colours, flattery, and advancement,
And all the bastard-glories this frame jets in
Horror, nor splendor, shadows fair nor fowl
Should force me shame my husband, wound my soul.
Couzen, y're welcome; this is kindly done of you
To visit the despis'd▪
I hope not so Couze,
The want of means cannot make you despis'd;
Love, not by wealth, but by desert is priz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Y'are pleas'd to help it well Couze.

LG.L: I am come to you,
Beside my visitation, to request you
To lay your wit to mine, which is but simple,
And help me to untie a few dark words
Made up in knots, they're of the Widows knitting,
That ties all sure; for my wit has not strength
Nor cunning to unloose 'em.
Good! what are they?
Though there be little comfort of my help▪
She wish'd Sir Olivers daughter and my self
Good fortune in our choices, and repented her
Of a rash oath she took when we were both Infants,
A secret to cozceal; but since all's well,
She holds it best to keep it unreveal'd.
Now what this is, Heaven knows.
Nor can I guess
The course of her whole life, and her dead husbands,
Was ever full of such dishonest riddles,
To keep right heirs from knowledge of their own:
And now I'm put i'th' minde on't, I believe
It was some price of Land or money given
By some departing friend upon their death-bed,
Perhaps to your self; and Sir Olivers daughter
May wrongfully enjoy it, and she hired
(For she was but an hireling in those days)
To keep the injury secret.
The most likeliest
That ever you could think on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Is it not?

LG.L: Sure Couze, I think you have untied the knot:
My thoughts lie at more ease, as in all other things,
In this I thank your help, and may you live
To conquer your own troubles, and cross ends,
As your are ready to supply your friends.
I thank you for the kinde truth of your heart,
In which I flourish when all means depart:
Sure in that oath of hers there sleeps some wrong
Done to my Kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Jane.
SP.P: Who'ld you speak withal?

SP.SPEAKER: Footm
SP.P: The Gentlewoman of this house, forsooth▪

SP.SPEAKER: Jane
SP.P: Whose Footman are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Footm.
SP.P: One Sir Gilbert Lambstons—.

SP.SPEAKER: Jane.
SP.P: Sir Gilbert Lambstons—there my Cousin walks.

SP.SPEAKER: Footm.
SP.P: Thank your good worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: How now, whence are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Footm.
SP.P: This Letter will make known.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Whence comes it Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Footm.
SP.P: From the Knight my Master, Sir Gilbert Lambston.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Return't, I'll receive none on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Footm.
SP.P: There it must lie then; I were as good run to Tyburn afoot, and hang my self at mine own charges, as carry it back again.

LG.L: Life, had he not his answer? What strange impudence
Governs in man, when Lust is Lord of him?
Thinks he me mad? cause I have no monies on Earth▪
That I'll go forfeit my estate in Heaven,
And live eternal Beggar? he shall pardon me,
That's my souls joynture, I'll starve ere I sell that.
Oh is he gone, and left the Letter here!
Yet I will read it, more to hate the writer.

LETTER.P: IF you desire to understand your own comfort, hear me out, ere you refuse me; I'm in the way now to d ub e the yearly means that first I offered you, and to sti you more to me, I'll empty your enemies Bags to maintain you; for the rich Widow, the Lady Golden-fleece, to whom I have been a longer Suiter, then you a longer ad∣versary, hath given me so much encouragement lately, insomuch that I am perfectly assured, the next meeting strikes the bargain: The happiness that follows this, 'twere idle to inform you of, onely consent to my desires, and the Widows Notch shall lie open to you. Thus much to your heart, I know y'e wise, farewel.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Thy Friend to his power, and another's Gilbert Lambston:

LG.L: In this poor Brief, what Volumes has he thrust,
Of treacherons Purjury, and adulterous Lust!
So foul a Monster does this wrong appear,
That I give pitty to mine enemy here
What a most fearful love raigns in some hearts,
That dare oppose all Judgment to get means,
And wed rich Widows, onely to keep Queans;
What a strange path he takes to my affection,
And thinks't the near'st way; 'twill never be;
Goes through mine enemies ground to come to me.
This Letter is most welcome; I repent now,
That my last anger threw thee at my feet,
My bosom shall receive thee.
'Tis good policy too,
To keep one that so mortally hates the Widow;
She'll have more care to keep it close her self,
And look what wind her revenge goes withal,
The self-same gale whisks up the sails of love;
I shall lose much good sport by that: Now my sweet Mistress.
Sir Gilbert! you change Suiters oft,
You were here in black but lately.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst
SP.P: My minde ne'r shifts though.

LG.L: A foul mind the whil'st:
But sure Sir, this is but a dissembling Glass
You sent before you; 'tis not possible
Your heart should follow your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Then may both perish.

LG.L: Do not wish that so soon Sir; Can you make
A three moneths love to a rich Widows Bed,
And lay her pillow under a Queans head?
I know you can't, how ere you may dissemble't;
You have a heart brought up better.
Faith you wrong me in't,
You shall not finde it so; I do protest to thee,
I will be Lord of all my promises,
And er't be long, thou shalt but turn a key,
And finde 'em in thy coffer; for my love
In matching with the Widow, is but policy
To strengthen my estate, and make me able
To set off all thy kisses with rewards,
That the worst weather our delights behold,
It may hail Pearl, and showre the Widows Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: You talk of a brave world Sir.

LG.L: 'Twill seem better
When golden happiness breaks forth it self
Out of the vast part of the Widows Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: And here it sets.

LG.L: Here shall the downfal be,
Her wealth shall rise from her, and set in thee.
You men have th'art to overcome poor women.
Pray give my thoughts the freedom of one day,
And all the rest take you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: I straight obey; this Bird's my own▪

LG.L: There is no happiness but has her sea∣son,
Herein the brightness of her vertue shines,
The husk falls off in time that long shuts up
The fruit in a dark prison; so sweeps by
The cloud of miseries from wretches eyes,
That yet, though faln, at length they see to rise,
The secret powers work wondrously, and duly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Why how now Kate?

LG.L: Oh are you come Sir? Husband,
Wake, wake, and let not patience keep thee poor,
Rouze up thy spirit from this falling slumber;
Make thy distress seem but a weeping dream,
And this the opening morning of thy comforts,
Wipe the Salt dew off from thy careful eyes,
And drink a draught of gladness next thy heart,
T'expel the infection of all poysonous sorrows.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: You turn me past my sences:

LG.L: Will you but second
The purpose I intend, I'll be first forward;
I crave no more of thee but a following spirit;
Will you but grant me that?
Why, what's the business
That should transport thee thu!
Hope of much good, no fear of the least ill;
Take that to comfort thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Yea?

LG.L: Sleep not on't, this is no slumbering business,
'Tis like the sweating sickness; I must keep
Your eyes still wake, y're gone if once you sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: I will not rest then, till thou hast thy wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Peruse this love paper as you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: A Letter?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Oliver Twilight, with Mr Sandfield, Philip, and Savorwit.

LG.L: Good Mr Sandfield, for the great af∣fection
You bear toward my Girl, I am well pleas'd
You should enjoy her Beauty; Heaven forbid Sir,
That I should cast away a proper Gentleman,
So far in love with a sowre mood, or so.
No, no, I'll not die guilty of a Lovers Neck-crack∣ing.
Marry, as for portion, there I leave you Sir
To the mercy of your destiny again,
I'll have no hand in that.
Faith something Sir;
Be't but t'express your love.
I have no desire Sir
To express my love that way, and so rest satisfied;
I pray take heed in urging that too much
You draw not my love from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Fates foresee Sir.

LG.L: Faith then you may go, seek out a high Steeple,
Or a deep water, there's no saving of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav:
SP.P: How naturally he plays upon himself!

LG.L: Marry if a wedding dinner, as I told you,
And three years board, well lodg'd in mine house,
And eating, drinking, and a sleeping portion
May give you satisfaction, I am your man Sir,
Seek out no other.
I am content to embrace it Sir,
Rather then hazard languishment, or ruine.
I love thee for thy wisdom; such a Son in law
Will chear a Fathers heart. Welcome sweet Master Sandfield,
Whether away boys, Philip?
To visit my Love Sir,
Old Mr. Sunsets Daughter.
That's my Philip,
Ply't hard, my good boys both, put'em to't finely.
One day, one dinner, and one house shall joyn you.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: That's our desire Sir.

LG.L: Pish; come hither Savorwit.
Observe my son, and bring me word, sweet boy,
Whether h'as a speeding wit or no in wooing.
That will I Sir;—that your own eyes might tell you,
I think it speedy, your Girl has a round belly.
How soon the comfortable shine of joy
Breaks through a cloud of grief!
The tears that I let fall for my dead wife,
Are dried up with the beams of my Girls fortunes.
Her life, her death, and her ten years distress,
Are e'n forgot with me; the love and care
That I ought her, her daughter shows it all;
I'can but be bestow'd, and there 'tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: How now, what news?

LG.L: There's a Dutch Merchant Sir, that's now come over,
Desires some conference with you.
How, a Dutch Merchant?
Pray send him into me,—what news with him tro?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dutch Merchant, with a little Dutch Boy in Great slops.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch Merch.
SP.P: Sir Oliver Twilight!

LG.L: That's my name indeed Sir,
I pray be covered Sir, y'are very welcome.
This is my business Sir; I took into my charge
A few words to deliver to your self
From a dear friend of yours, that wonders strangely
At your unkinde neglect.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Indeed? what might he be Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: Nay, y'are i'th' wrong gender now,—'Tis that distressed Lady, your good wife Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: What say you Sir, my wife?

LG.L: Yes Sir, your wife!
This strangeness now of yours seems more to harden
Th'uncharitable neglect she tax't you for.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Pray give me leave Sir, is my wife a∣live?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: Came any news to you Sir, to th'con∣trary?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Yes by my faith did there.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: Pray how long since Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: 'Tis now some ten weeks.

LG.L: Faith within this moneth Sir,
I saw her talk and eat; and those in our Kalender
Are signs of life and health.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Mass so they are in ours.

LG.L: And these were the last words her pas∣sion threw me.
No grief, quoth she, sits to my heart so close
As his unkindness, and my daughters loss.
You make me weep, and wonder, for I swear
I sent her ransome, and that daughter's here.
Here! that will come well to lighten her of one grief.
I long to see her for the pitious moan
Her Mother made for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: That shall you Sir.—Within there!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Call down my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Yes Sir.

LG.L: Here's strange budgelling; I tell you Sir,
Those that I put in trust, were neer me too,
A man would think they should not juggle with me;
My own son, and my servant, no worse people Sir.
And yet oft-times Sir, what worse Knave to a man
Then he that eats his meat?
Troth you say true Sir;
I sent 'em simply, and that news they brought,
My wife had left the world, and with that Son
I sent to her, this brought his sister home:
Look you Sir, this is she.
If my eye sin not Sir,
Or misty error falsifie the glass,
I saw that face at Antwerp in an Inn
When I set forth first to fetch home this boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: How, in an Inn?

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: Oh I am betray'd I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: How do you yong Mistress?

LG.L: Your eyes wrong your tongue Sir,
And makes you sin in both; I am not she.
No? then I never saw face twice▪ Si Olive Twilight
I tell you my free thoughts, I fear y'are blinded;
I do not like this story; I doubt much
The sister is as false as the dead mother:
Ye! say you so Sir? I see nothing lets me, but to doubt so too then:
So, to your Chamber, we have done with you.
I would be glad you had; here's a strange storm.
Sift it out well Sir; till anon I leave you Sir.
Business commands me hence, but as a pledge
Of my return, I'll leave my little son with you,
Who yet takes little pleasure in this Country,
Cause he can speak no English, all Dutch he▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: A fine boy, he's welcome Sir to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: Where', your leg, and your thanks to the Gentleman.

LG.L: War es you neighgen an you thonkes you.
Ick donck you, ver ew Edermon vrendly Kite.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: What says he Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: He thanks you for your kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Pretty Knave!

LG.L: Had not some business held me by the way,
This news had come to your ear ten days ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: It comes too soon now me thinks; I'm your debtor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: But I could wish it Sir for better ware:

LG.L: We must not be our own chusers in our fortunes:
Here's a cold Pye to breakfast: Wife alive,
The daughter doubtful, aud the money spent!
How am I juggled withal?
It hits y'faith Sir,
The work goes even.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Oh come, come, come, are you come Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Life, what's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: There's a new reckoning come in since.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Pox on't, I thought all had been paid, I can't abide these after-reckonings.

LG.L: I pray come near Sir, let's be acquaint∣ed with you,
Your bold enough abroad with my purse Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: No more then beseems manners and good use Sir:

LG.L: Did not you bring me word some ten weeks since.
My wife was dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Yes, true Sir, very true Sir.

LG.L: Pray stay, and take my horse along with you,
And with the ransome that I sent for her
That you redeem'd my daughter:
Right as can be Sir,
I never found your worship in a false tale yet:
I thank you for your good word Sir; but I'm like
To finde your worship now in two at once:

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: I should be sorry to hear that▪

LG.L: I believe you Sir,
Within this moneth my wife was sure alive.
There's six weeks bated of your ten weeks lye,
As has been credibly reported to me
By a Dutch Merchant, Father to that boy
But now come over, and the words scarce cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: O strange!—'tis a most rank untruth; where is he Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: He will not be long absent.

LG.L: All's confounded.
If he were here, I'll tell him to his face Sir,
He wears a double tongue; that's Dutch and English—
Will the Boy say't?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: 'Lass he can speak no English.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: All the better, I'll gabble something to him. Hoyste Kaloiste, Kalooskine vou, dar sune, Alla Gas∣kin?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch Boy.
SP.P: Ick wet neat watt hey zackt, Ick un∣verston ewe neat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Why la, I thought as much!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: What says the Boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: He says his Father is troubled with an imper∣fection at one time of the Moon, and talks like a Mad∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv:
SP.P: What does the Boy say so?

LG.L: I knew there was somewhat in't;
Your wife alive! Will you believe all tales Sir?
Nay more Sir, he told me, he saw this wench
Which you brought home, at Antwerp in an Inn;
Tell me, I'm plainly couzen'd of all hands,
'Tis not my daughter neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: All's broke out.
How? not your daughter Sir? I must to' again. Quisquinikin Salamare, alla pisse kickin Sows-clows, Hoff Tofte le cumber shaw, bouns bus bexsceeno.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch Boy.
SP.P: Ick an sawth no int hein clappon de heeke, I dinke ute zein zennon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Oh zein zennon! Ah ha, I thought how 'twould prove i'th' end; the Boy says they never came near Antwerp, a quite contrary way, round a∣bout by Parma.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: What's the same zein zennon?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: That is, he saw no such wench in an Inn; 'tis well I came in such happy time to get it out of the Boy before his Father returned again; pray be wary Sir; the world's subtle, come and pretend a charitable business in policy, and work out a peice of money on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Mass, art advis'd of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: The Age is cunning Sir, beside a Dutchman will live upon any ground, and work Butter out of a Thistle.

LG.L: Troth thou say'st true in that, they're the best thrivers
In Turnips, Hartichalks, and Cabishes:
Our English are not like them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: O fy, no Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Ask him from whence they came, when they came hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: That I will Sir,—Culluaron lagooso, lageen, lagan, rufft, punkatee.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch Boy.
SP.P: Nimd aweigh de cack.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: What, what, I cannot blame him then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: What says he to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: The poor Boy blushes for him; he tells me his Father came from making merry with certain of his Countrymen, and he's a little steep'd in English Beer; there's no heed to be taken of his tongue now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Hoyda! how com'st thou by all this, I heard him speak but three words to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: O Sir, the Dutch is a very wide Language; you shall have ten English words even for one; as for example, Gullder-goose, there's a word for you Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Why what's that same Gullder-goose?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav
SP.P: How do you and all your generation—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Why 'tis impossible? how prove you that Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: 'Tis thus distinguisht; Sir, Gull, how do you? Der, and; Goose, your generation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv:
SP.P: 'Tis a most saucy Language, how cam'st thou by't?

LG.L: I was brought up to London in an Eelship;
There was the place I caught it first by th'tale:
I shall be tript anon; Pox, would I were gone.
I'll go seek out your son Sir, you shall hear
What thunder he'll bring with him.
Do, do Savorwit,
I'll have you all face to face.
Cuds me, what else Sir?
And you take me so near the net again,
I'll give you leave to squat me; I have scap'd fairly.
We are undone in Dutch; all our three moneths roguery
Is now come over in a Butter Firkin.
Never was man so tost between two tales!
I know not which to take, not which to trust;
The Boy here is the likeliest to tell truth,
Because the worlds corruption is not yet
At full years in him; sure he cannot know
What deceit means, 'tis English yet to him.
And when I think again, why should the Father
Dissemble for no profit? he gets none,
What ere he hopes for, and I think he hopes not.
The man's in a good case, being old and weary,
He dares not lean his arm on his sons shoulder,
For fear he lie i'th' dirt, but must be rather
Beholding to a stranger for his prop.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: I make bold once again Sir for a Boy here.

LG.L: O Sir y're welcome, pray resolve me one thing Sir:
Did you within this moneth, with your own eyes,
See my wife living?
I nev'r borrowed any.
Why should you move that question Sir? dissembling
Is no part of my living.
I have reason
To urge it so far Sir (pray be not angry though)
Because my man was here since your departure,
Withstands all stiffly, and to make it clearer,
Question'd your Boy in Dutch; who as he told me,
Return'd this answer first to him: That you
Had imperfection at one time o'th' Moon,
Which made you talk so strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: How, how's this! Zeicke▪ yongon, ick ben ick quelt medien dullek heght, ee untoit van the mon, an koot uram'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch Boy.
SP.P: Wee ek. heigh lieght in ze Bokkas, dee't site.

LG.L: Why la you Sir? here's no such thing,
He says he lies in's throat that says it.
Then the Rogue lies in's throat, for he told me so,
And that the boy should answer at next question,
That you ne'r saw this wench, nor came near Ant∣werp.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: Ten thousand Devils! Zeicke hee ewe ek kneeght, yongon, dat wee neeky by Antwarpon ne don cammen no seene de doughter Dor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch Boy.
SP.P: Ick hub ham hean sulka dongon he zaut, hei es a skllom an rubbout?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: He says he told him no such matter he's a Knave and a Rascal.

LG.L: Why, how am I abus'd? Pray tell me one thing,
What's Gulldergoose in Dutch?

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: How Gulldergoose! there's no such thing in Dutch, it may be an Ass in English.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Oliv.
SP.P: Hoyda! then am I that Ass in plain English; I am grosly couzen'd, most inconside∣rately.

LG.L: Pray let my house receive you for one night,
That I may quit these Rascals, I beseech you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: If that may stead you Sir, I'll not refuse you.

LG.L: A thousand thanks, and welcome:
On whom can Fortune more spit out her foam,
Work'd on abroad, and plai'd upon at home?

DIV3.HEAD: Scaen 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Weatherwise the Gull, meeting two or three bringing out a Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: SO, set the Table ready, the Widow's i'd' next room, looking upon my Clock with the days and the moneths, and the change of the Moon: I'll fetch her in presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: She's not so mad to be fetcht in with the Moon, I warrant you: A man must go roundlier to work with a Widow, then to woo her with the Hand of a Dial, or stir up her Blood with the striking part of a clock, I should ne'r stand to show her such things in Chamber.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Weatherwise with the Widow, Sir Gilbert Lambston, Mr. Pepperton, Mr. Overdon.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Welcome sweet Widow to a Batchelors house here, a single man; I, but for two or three Maids that I keep.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Why are you double with them then?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: An exceeding good mourning wit; Wo∣men are wiser then ever they were, since they wore Doublets.—You must think sweet Widow, if a man keep Maids, they're under his subjection.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: That's most true Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: They have no reason to have a Lock, but the Master must have a Key to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: To him Sir Gilbert, he fights with me at a wrong weapon now.

LG.L: Nay, and Sir Gilbert strike, my weapon falls,
I fear no thrust but his; here are more shooters,
But they have shot two Arrows without heads,
They cannot stick i'th' Butt yet; hold out Knight,
And I'll cleave the black pin in 'th' midst o'th' white.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Nay, and he led me into a Closet Sir, where he shew'd me dyet drinks for several moneths, as Scurvigrass for April, Clarified Whey for June, and the like

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: O Madam, he is a most necessary pro∣perty—An't be but to save our credit, ten pound in a Banquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Go! y're a wag Sir Gilbert.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P:
How many there be in the world of his Fortunes, that prick their own Calves with Bryers, to make an easie passage for others; or like a toiling
Usurer, sets his son a hors-back in Cloth of Gold∣breeches, while he himself goes 'ch' Devil a foot in a pair of old Strossers.

LG.L: But shall I give a more familiar sign?
His are the Sweet-meats, but the kisses mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Overd.
SP.P: Excellent! a pox a' your Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Saucy courting has brought all modest wooing clean out of fashion: You shall have few Maids now a days got without rough handling; all the Towns so us'd to't, and most commonly too they're joyn'd before they're married; because they'll be sure to be fast enough.

LG.L: Sir, since he strives t'oppose himself against us,
Le's so combine our friendships in our straits,
By all means graceful to assist each other;
For I protest it shall as much glad me
To see your happiness, and his disgrace,
As if the wealth were mine, the love, the place.
And with the like faith I reward your friendship;
I'll break the baudy ranks of his discourse,
And scatter his libidinous whispers streight, M∣dam!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: How cheer you Gentlemen?

LG.L: Pox on 'em,
They wak'd me out of a fine sleep, three minutes
Had fastned all the treasure in mine arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: You took no note of this conceit, it seems, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Twelve Trenchers, upon every one a moneth, January, February, March, April——

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: I, and their Poesies under 'em.

LG.L: Pray what says May? she's the Spring Lady▪
Now gallant May in her array▪
Doth make the field pleasant and gay.
This moneth of June use clarified Whey,
Boil'd with cold herbs, and drink alway.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Drink't all away, he should say?

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: 'Twere mach better indeed, and whole∣somer for his Liver.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: September's a good one here Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Oh have you chose your moneth, let's hear't Sir Gilbert!

LG.L: Now may'st thou Physicks safely take,
And bleed, and bathe for thy healths sake.
Eat Figs and Grapes, and spicery,
For to refresh thy Members dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Thus it is still, when a mans simple meaning lights among wantons; how many honest words have suffered corruption, since Chaucers days? A Virgin would speak those words then, that a very Midwife would blush to hear now, if she have but so much blood left to make up an ounce of grace. And who is this long on, but such wags as you, that use your words like your wenches? you cannot let 'em pass honestly by you, but you must still have a flirt at 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: You have paid some of us home, Ma∣dam.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: If conceit will strike this stroke, have at the Widows Plumb-tree; I'll put 'em down all for a Banquet. Widow and Gentlemen, my Friends and Servants, I make you wait long here for a Batchelors pittance.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: O Sir, y'are pleas'd to be modest.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: No by my troth, Widow, you shall finde it otherwise.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Banquet, and six of his Tenants with the Twelve Signs, made like Banquetting-stuff.
Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricorn, Aquarius, and Pisces.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What the Twelve Signs!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: These are the Signs of my love, Widow▪

LG.L: Worse meat would have serv'd us Sir; by my Faith
I'm sorry you should be at such charges Sir,
To feast us a whole moneth together here.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Widow, thou'rt welcome a whole moneth, and ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: And what be those Sir that brought in the Banquet?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Those are my Tenants, they stand for Fast∣ing days.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Or the six weeks in Lent.

LG.L: Y're i'th' right Sir Gilbert.
Sweet Widow take your place at Aries here,
That's the head Sign—, a Widow is the head
Till she be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What is she then?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The middle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: 'Tis happy she's no worse.

LG.L: Taurus, Sir Gilbert Lambston that's for you;
They say you're a good Town▪Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: O spare your friends Sir.

LG.L: And Gemini for Master Pepperton,
He had two boys at once by his last wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: I hear the Widow finde no fault with that Sir.

LG.L: Cancer the Crab for Master Overdon';
For when a thing's past fifty, it grows crooked.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Now for your self Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Take no care for me Widow,

I can be any where; here's Leo, heart and hack, Vir∣go, guts and belly; I can go lower yet, and yet fare better, sence Sagittarius fits me the thighs; I care not if I be about the thighs, I shall finde meat enough

LG.L: But under pardon Sir,
Though you be Lord o'th' Feast, and the conceit both,
Methinks it had been proper for the Banquet
To have had the Signs all fil'd, and no one idle.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I know it had; but whose fault's that Widow? you should have got you more Suitors to have stopt the gaps.

LG.L: Nay sure, they should get us, and not we them;
There be your Tenants Sir; we are not proud,
You may bid them sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: By th'mass it's true too,

Then sit down Tenants once with your hats on, but spare the meat, I charge you, as you hope for new Leases: I must make my Signs draw out a moneth yet, with a bit every morning to break-fast, and at Full Moon with a whole one; that's restorative; sit round, sit round, and do not speak sweet Tenants, you may be bold enough, so you eat but little; how like you this now Widow?

LG.L: It shows well Sir,
And like the good old Hospitable fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow▪
SP.P: How! like a good old Hospital; my Mi∣stres▪ makes an arrant gull on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: But yet methinks there wants cloaths for the feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P:
That part's uncovered yet,—push
no matter for the feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Yes, if the feet catch cold, the head will feel it.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Why then you may draw up your legs, and lie rounder together.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: H'as answered you well Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: And you draw up your legs too, Widow, my Tenant will feel you there, for he's one of the Calves.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Better and better Sir, your wit fattens as he feeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Sh'as took the Calf from his Tenant, and put it upon his ground now.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mistress Low-water as a gallant Gentleman, her Husband like a Serving-man after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: How now my Ladies man, what's the news Sir!

LG.L: Madam, there's a yong Gentleman below,
H'as earnest business to your Ladiship

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Another Suiter I hold my life, Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What is he Sir?

LG.L: He seems a Gentleman,
That's the least of him, and yet more I know not.
Under the leave o'th▪ Master of the house here,
I would he were admitted.
With all my heart, Widow, I fear him not,
Come Cut and Long tail.
I have the least fear,
And the most firmness, nothing can shake me.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P:
If he be a Gentleman, he's welcome; there's a Sign does nothing, and that's fit for a Gen∣tleman; the feet will be kept warm enough▪ now
you Widow; for if he be a right Gentleman, he has his stockins warm'd, and he wears socks beside; partly for warmth, partly for cleanliness; and if he observe Fridays too, he comes excellent well. Pisces will be a fine Fish dinner for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Why then you mean Sir, he shall sit as he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I, and he were a Lord, he shall not sit a∣bove my Tenants▪ I'll not have two Lords to them; so I may go look my rent in another mans Breeches; I was not brought up to be so unmannerly?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low
SP.P: I have pickt out a bold time; much god do you Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Y're welcome as I may say Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Pardon my rudeness, Madam.

LG.L: No such fault Sir;
Your too severe to your self, our judgment quits you.
Please you to do as we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Thanks good Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Make room Gentlemen.

LG.L: Sit still Tenants, I'll call in all your old
Leass, and rack you else.

SP.SPEAKER: All Tenants.
SP.P: Oh sweet Landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Take my cloak sirrah; if any be di∣sturb'd, I'll not sit Gentlemen,
I see my place.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: A proper woman turn'd gallant! if the Widow refuse me, I care not if I be a suiter to him: I have known those who have been as mad, and given half their living for a Male companion.

LG.L: How Pisces! is that mine?
'Tis a conceied Banquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: If you love any fish, pray fall to Sir; if you had come sooner, you might have happened a∣mong some of the flesh Signs, but now they'r all taken up; Virgo had been a good dish for you, had not one of my Tenants been somewhat busie with her.

LG.L: Pray let him keep her Sir, give me meat fresh,
I'd rather have whole fish then broken flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: What say you to a bit of Taurus?

LG.L: No, I thank you Sir,
The Bull's too rank for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: How Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Too rank Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Fy, I shall strike you dumb like all your fellows:

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: What with your heels, or horns?

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Perhaps with both.

LG.L: It must be at dead Low-water,
When I'm dead then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low:
SP.P: 'Tis a brave Kate, and nobly spoke of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: This quarrel must be drown'd—Picka∣dille, my Ladies Fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Your, your own man Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Prethee step in to one o'th' Maids.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: That I will Sir, and thank you too.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Nay, hark you Sir, call for my Sun cup presently, I'd forgot it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: How, your Sun-cup? some cup I warrant that he stole out o'th' Sun-Tavern?

LG.L: The more I look on him, the more I thirst for't;
Methinks his beauty does so far transcend,
Turns the Signs back, makes that the upper end;
How cheer you Widow? Gentlemen how chear you?
Fair weather in all quarters, the Sun will peep anon, I have sent one for him;
In the mean time I'll tell you a tale of these.
This Libra here that keeps the scale so even,
Was i'th' old time an honest Chandlers Widow,
And had one daughter which was called Virgo,
Which now my hungry Tenant has deflowr'd.
This Virgo passing for a Maid, was sued to
By Sagittarius there, a gallant shooter,
And Aries his head-rival; but her old crabbed Uncle Cancer here, dwelling in Crooked lane,
Still crost the marriage minding to bestow her
Upon one Scorpio, a rich Usurer;
The girl loathing that match, fell into folly
With one Taurus, a Gentleman in Townbul-street;
By whom she had two twins, those Gemini there.
Of which two brats, she was brought a bed in Leo,
At the Red Lion about Tower-hill.
Being in this distress, one Capricorn,
An honest Citizen pittied her case, and married her to Aquarius, an old Water bearer,
And Pisces was her living ever after,
At Standard she sold fish, where he drew water.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: It shall be yours Sir▪

LG.L: Meat and mirth too, y're lavish!
Your purse and tongue has been at cost to day Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: You may challenge all comers at these twelve weapons I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Your Sun-cup call you it! 'tis a simple voy∣age that I have made here; I have left my Doublet within, for fear I should sweat through my Jerkin, and thrown a Cypress over my face for fear of Sun∣burning.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: How now, whose this? why sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Can you endure it Mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Endure, what fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Fill the cup Coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Nay an't be no hotter, I'll go put on my Doublet again.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: What a whoreson-sot is this! prethee fill the cup fellow, and giv't the Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Sirrah, how stand you? bestow your service there upon her Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What's here a Sun?

LG.L: It does betoken Madam
A chearful day to some body?
It rises
Full in the face of you fair Sign, and yet
By course he is the last must feel the heat.
Here Gentlemen to you all, for you know the Sun must go through the twelve Signs.
Most wittily Widow; you jump with my conceit right,
There's not a hair between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Give it Sir Gilbert.

LG.L: I am the next through whom the golden flame
Shines, when 'tis spent in thy Celestial Ram,
The poor Feet there must wait and cool a while▪
We have our Time Sir, Joy and we shall meet,
I have known the proud Neck lie between the Feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: So round it goes.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I like this drinking world well.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: So filt him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Fil't me! why I drunk last Sir▪

LG.L: I know you did, but Gemini must drink twice,
Unless you mean that one of them shall be choak'd.
Fly from my heart all variable thoughts;
She that's entic'd by every pleasing object,
Shall finde small pleasure, and as little rest.
This Knave hath lov'd me long, he's best and worthi∣est,
I cannot but in honor see him requited—Sir Gil∣bert Lambston.
How? pardon me sweet Lady,
That with a bold tongue I strike by your words,
Sir Gilbert Lambston?

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Yes Sir, that's my name.

LG.L: There should be a rank Villain of that name,
Came you out of that house—

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: How, Sir Slave!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Fall to your Bull, leave roaring till a∣non:

LG.L: Yet again! and you love me Gentlemen, let's have no roaring here.
If I had thought that, I'd have sent my Bull to the Bear garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Why so you should have wanted one of your Signs.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: But I may chance want two now, and they fall together by the ears.

LG.L: What's the strange fire that works in these two Creatures?
Cold Signs both, yet more hot then all their fel∣lows—

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Ho Sol in Pisces! the Sun's in New Fish∣street; here's an end of this course.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Madam, I am bold to remember your wor∣ship for a years wages, and an Livery-cloak.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid:
SP.P: How, will you shame me, had you not both last week fool?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I, but there's another year past since that.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Would all your wit could make that good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I am sure the Sun has run through all the twelve Signs since, and that's a year, this Gentlemen can witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The fool will live Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I as long as your eyes are open, I warrant him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Sirrah!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Does your worship call?

LG.L: Commend my love and service to the Widow,
Desire her Ladiship to taste that morsel.
This is the bit I watcht for all this while;
But it comes duly.
And wherein has this name of mine of∣fended,
That y're so liberal of your infamous titles?
I but a stranger to thee, it must be known Sir
Ere we two part.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Marry and reason good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: O strike me cold—this should be your hand Sir Gilbert?

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Why, make you question of that Madam? 'tis one of the Letters I sent you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Much good do you Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: How now? what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Look to the Widow, she paints white, some Aqua Coelist is for my Lady, run vilain.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Aqua Solister; can no body help her case but a Lawyer? and so many Suiters here?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: O treachery unma ch't, unheard of!

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: How do you Madam?

LG.L: Oh impudence as foul! does my disease
Ask how I do? can it torment my heart,
And look with a fresh colour in my face?

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst▪
SP.P: What's this! what's this!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I am sorry for this qualm Widow.

LG.L: He that would know a villain when he meets him,
Let him ne'r go to a Conjurer; here's a glass
Will show him without money, and far truer.
Preferver of my state, pray tell me Sir,
That I may pay you all my thanks together;
What blest hap brought that Letter to your hand
From me, so fast lockt in mine enemies power?
I will resolve you Madam: I have a Kinsman
Somewhat infected with that wanton pitty
Which men bestow on the distress of women,
Especially if they be fair and poor,
With such hot Charity, which indeed is Lust;
He sought t'entice, as his repentance told me,
Her whom you call your enemy, the wife
To a poor Gentleman, one Low▪ water.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Right, right the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Had it been right, 't'ad now been.

LG.L: And according to the common rate of sinners,
Offer'd large maintenance, which with her seem'd nothing;
For if she would consent, she told him roundly,
There was a Knight had bid more at one minute
Then all his wealth could compass; and withal,
Pluckt out that Letter as it were in scorn;
Which by good fortune he put up in jest,
With promise that the Writ should be returnable
The next hour of his meeting. (But sweet Madam)
Out of my love and zeal, I did so practise
The part upon him of an urgent wooer,
That neither he nor that return'd more to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: Plague a that Kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Here's a gallant Rascal!

LG.L: Sir you have appear'd so noble in this action,
So full of worth and goodness, that my thanks
Will rather shame the Bounty of my minde,
Then do it honor: Oh thou treacherous villain!
Does thy Faith bear such fruit? are these the blos∣soms of a hundred Oaths
Shot from thy bosom? was thy love so spightful,
It could not be content to mock my heart,
Which is in love, a misery too much,
But must extend so far to the quick ruine
Of what was painfully got, carefully left me;
And 'mongst a world of yeilding-needy women,
Chuse no one to make merry with my sorrows,
And spend my wealth on, in adulterous surfeits.
But my most mortal enemy—O despightful!
Is this thy practice? follow it, 'twill advance thee:
Go, beguile on; have I so happily found
What many a Widow has with sorrow tasted,
Even when my Lip touch't the contracting Cup,
Ev'n then to see the Spider; 'twas miraculous!
Crawl with thy poysons hence, and for thy sake
I'll never covet Titles, and more Riches,
To fall into a gulf of hate and laughter:
I'll marry Love hereafter, I've enough;
And wanting that, I have nothing—There's thy way.

SP.SPEAKER: Overd
SP.P: Do you hear Sir? you must walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Hear't! thrust him down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Out of my house you treacherous, leche∣rous Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lambst.
SP.P: All curses scatter you.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Life, do you thunder here; if you had staid a little longer, I'd have rip't out some of my Bull out of your Belly again.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: 'Twas a most noble discovery; we must love you for ever for't.

LG.L: Sir, for your Banquet and your mirth we thank you;
You Gentlemen, for your kinde company:
But you, for all my merry days to come,
Or this had been the last else.
Love and Fortune
Had more care of your safety, peace and state Ma∣dam.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Now will I thrust in fo'rt.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: I'm for my self now.

LG.L: What's fifty years? 'tis mans best time and season;
Now the nights gone, the Widow will hear reason:
Now, now! the Suiters flatter, hold on Kate,
The Hen may pick the meat, while the Cocks prate.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr Sandfield, Philip, Sir Oliver Twilights Son with Savorwit.

LG.L: If thou talk'st longer, I shall turn to Mar∣ble,
And death wil! stop my hearing▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Horrible fortune!

LG.L: Nay Sir our building is so far defac'd,
There is no stuff left to raise up a hope.
Oh with more patience could my flesh en∣dure
A score of wounds, and all their several searchings,
Then this that thou hast told me.
Would that Flemmish Ram
Had ne'r come near our house; there's no going home
As long as he has a Nest there, and his yong one
A little Flanders Egg, new fleg'd: they gape for Pork, and I shall be made meat for'em.
'Tis not the bare news of my Mothers life
(May she live long and happy,) that afflicts me
With half the violence that the latter draws;
Though in that news I have my share of grief,
As I had share of sin; and a foul neglect,
It is my Loves betraying; that's the sting
That strikes through flesh and spirit; and sence no wit
From thee, in whom I ne'r saw ebb till now;
Nor comforts from a faithful friend can ease me,
I'll try the goodness of a third companion,
What he'll do for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Hold! why friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Why Master? is this all your kindness Sir: offer to steal into another Country, and ne'r take your leave on's: Toth, I take it unkindly at your hands Sir; but I'll put it up for once: Faith there was no Conscience in this Sir; leave me here to en∣dure all weathers, whilst you make your oul de like a Juglers Egg upon the point of a Raper▪ By my troth Sir, y're too blame in't; you might have gi∣ven us an inckling of your journey; perhaps others would as fain have gone as you.

LG.L: Burns this Clay-lamp of miserable life,
When Joy, the Oyl that feeds it, is dried up?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter his Mother new landed, with a Gentleman a Scholler, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: He has remov'd his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: So it seems, Madam.

LG.L: I'll ask that Gentleman;—pray can you tell me Sir
Which is Sir Oliver Twilights?
Few can better, Gentlewoman;
It is the next fair house your eye can fix on.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I thank you Sir, go on, he had a son about some ten years since.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: That son still lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth
SP.P: I pray how does he Sir?

LG.L: Faith much about my health, (that's never worse)
If you have any business to him, Gentlewoman,
I can cut short your journey to the house;
I'm all that ever was of the same kinde.
Oh my sweet son! never fell fresher joy
Upon the heart of Mother; this is he Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: My seven years travel has e'n worm him out Of my remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Oh this geer's worse and worse!

LG.L: I am so wonder-struck at your blest pre∣sence,
That through amaz'd Joy, I neglect my duty!

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Rise, and a thousand blessings spring up with thee.

LG.L: I would we had but one in the mean time,
Let the rest grow at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: But know you not this Gentleman yet son?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: It take its Mr Beveril.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: My name's Beveril, Sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Right welcome to my bosom▪

LG.L: You'ld not think son,
How much I am beholding to this Gentleman,
As far as freedom; he laid out the ransom,
Finding me so distress'd.
'Twas worthily done Sir,
And I shall ever rest your servant for't.
You quite forget your worth: 'Twas my good hap Sir,
To return home that way, after some travels;
Where finding your good Mother so distress'd,
I could not but in pitty see her releas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: It was a noble Charity Sir, Heaven quit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: It comes at last.

LG.L: I left a sister here,
New married when I last took leave of England.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Oh! Mistress Low-water▪

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Pray Sir, how does she!

LG.L: So little comfort I can give you Sir,
That I would fain excuse my self, for silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Why what's the worst Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Wrongs has made her poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: You strike my heart—Alas good Gentle∣woman!

LG.L: Here's a Gentleman,
You know him, Mr Sandfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I crave pardon Sir▪

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: He can resolve you, from her Kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: Welcome to England, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Thanks good Sir,

LG.L: Now there's no way to 'scape, I'm compas'd round;
My shame is like a prisoner set with Halbards.
Pish Master, Master, 'tis yong flood again,
And you can take your time now, away quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Push, thou'st a swimming head.

LG.L: Will you but hear me?
When did you lose your tide, when I set forth with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: That's true:

LG.L: Regard me then, though you have no feeling;
I would not hang by th'Thumbs with a good will.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil
SP.P: I hang by th'heart Sir, and would fain have ease.

LG.L: Then this or none: Flie to your Mothers pitty,
For that's the Court must help you; y'are quite gone
At Common Law, no Counsellor can hear you
Confess your follies, and ask pardon for'em.
Tell her the state of all things, stand not nicely,
The meat's too hard to be minc'd now; she breeds yong bones by this time?
Deal plainly, Heaven will bless thee; turn out all
And shake your pockets after it: Beg, weep, kneel, any thing, 'twill break no bones man.
Let her not rest, take breathing time, nor leave thee
Till thou hast got her help.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Lad, I conceive thee.

LG.L: About it then, it requires haste, do't well;
There', but a short street between us and Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Ah my poor sister!

LG.L: 'Lass good Gentlewoman▪
My heart ev'n weeps for her:—I son, we'll go now.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: May I crave one word Madam?

LG.L: With me son?
The more the better welcome.
Now, now, luck:
I pray not often, the last Prayer I made
Was nine year old last Bartholomew-Tide;
'Twould have been a jolly chopper, and ''ad liv'd till this time.
Why do your words start back; are they afraid
Of her that ever lov'd them!

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I have a suit to you Madam.

LG.L: You have told me that already; pray what is't?
If't be so great, my present state refuse it,
I shall be abler, then command and use it:
What er't be, let me have warning to provide for't.
Provide forgiveness then, for that's the want
My conscience feels; O my wilde youth has led me
Into unnatural wrongs against your freedom once:
I spent the ransom which my father sent,
To set my pleasures free, while you lay captive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: He does it finely faith.

LG.L: And is this all now?
You use me like a stranger, pray stand up.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Rather fall flat, I shall deserve yet worse.

LG.L: What ere your faults are, esteem me stil a friend,
Or else you wrong me more in asking pardon,
Then when you did the wrong, you ask'd it for:
And since you have prepar'd me to forgive you,
Pray let me know for what, the first faults nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: 'Tis a sweet Lady every inch of her.

LG.L: Here comes the wrong then that drives home the rest.
I saw a face at Antwerp, that quite drew me
From Conscience and Obedience; in that fray
I lost my heart, I must needs lose my way;
There went the ransom, to redeem my minde,
Sreed of the money, I brought over her;
And to cast mists before my Fathers eyes,
Told him it was my sister, lost so long,
And that your self was dead.—You see the wrong.
This is but youthful still.—O that word sister
Afflicts me when I think on't: I forgive thee
As freely as thou didst it. For alas
This may be cal'd good dealing to some parts,
That love and youth plays daily among sons.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: She helps our Knavery well, that's one good comfort.

LG.L: But such is the hard plight my state lives in,
That 'twixt forgiveness, I must sin again,
And seek my help where I bestow'd my wrongs.
O Mother pitty once, though against reason!
Cause I can merit none, though my wrongs grieve you;
Yet let it be your glory to relieve me.
Wherein have I given cause yet of mi∣strust,
That you should doubt my succor, and my love?
Show me but in what kinde I may bestow 'em.
There came a Dutchman with report this day,
That you were living.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Came he so lately?

LG.L: Yes Madam.
Which news so struck my Father on the sudden,
That he grows jealous of my faith in both.
These five hours have I kept me from his sight,
And wish'd my self eternally so hid:
And surely, had not your blest presence quickned
The flame of life in me, all had gone out.
Now to confirm me to his trust again,
And settle much aright in his opinion;
Say but she is my sister, and all's well.
You ask devotion like a bashful beggar,
That pure need urges, and not lazy impudence;
And to express how glad I am to pitty you,
My bounty shall flow over your demand.
I will not onely with a constant breath
Approve that, but excuse thee for my death▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Why here's a woman made, as a man would wish to have her!

LG.L: Oh I am plac'd higher in happiness,
Then whence I fell before!
We're brave fellows once again, and we can keep our own:
Now Hoffte Toftee, our Pipes play as loftily?

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: My sister fled!

LG.L: Both fled, that's the news now; Want must obey;
Oppressions came so thick, they could not stay.
Mean are my fortunes, yet had I been nigh,
Distress nor wrong should have made Vertue flie.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Spoke like a Brother, worthy such a sister;

LG.L: Grief's like a new wound, heat beguiles the sence,
For I shall feel this smart more three days hence.
Come Madam, sorrow's rude, and forgets manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Our knavery is for all the world like a shift∣ing Bankrupt, it breaks in one place, and sets up in another: He tryes all trades, from a Goldsmith to a Tobacco-seller; we try all shifts, from an Outlaw to a Flatterer: He couzens the Husband, and com∣pounds with the Widow; we couzen my Master, and compound with my Mistress; onely here I turn o'th' right hand from him, He is known to live like a Ras∣cal, when I am thought to live like a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I have sent in one to th'Widow.

LG.L: Well said Kate,
Thou ply'st thy business close,—The coast is clear yet!
Let me but have warning,
shall make pretty shift with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: That thou shalt wench.

LG.L: My Lady Sir commends her kindly to you,
the third part of an hour Sir,
res your patience,—Two or three of her Te∣nants out of Kent
Will hold her so long busied.
Thank you Sir.
it I should attend her time and leisure;
Those were my Tenants once, but what relief
Is there in what hath been, or what I was?
'Tis now that makes the man. A last years feast
Yeilds little comfort for the present humor;
He starves that feeds his hopes with what his past:
—How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: They're come, newly alighted.

LG.L: Peace, peace,
I'll have a trick for 'em,—Look you second me well now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: I warrant thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I must seem very imperious, I can tell you; therefore if I should chance to use you rough∣ly, pray forgive me beforehand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: With all my heart Kate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: You must look for no obedience in those clothes, that lies in the Pocket of my Gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Well, well, I will not then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I hear 'em coming, step back a little Sir: Where be those fellows? who looks out there? is there ne'r a Knave i'th' house to take those Gentle∣mens horses? where wait you to day? how stand you? like a dreaming Goose in a corner, the Gen∣tlemens horses forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Yes an't like your worship.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Master Weatherwise, Mr Pepperton, and Mr Overdon, Suiters▪

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: What's here, a strange alteration?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath:
SP.P: A new Lord? would I were upon my Mares back again then.

LG.L: Pray Gentlemen pardon the rudeness of these Grooms,
I hope they will be brought to better fashion;
In the mean time y'are welcome Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: We thank you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Life here's quick work! I'll hold my life h'as struck the Widow i'th' right Planet, Venus in Cauda? I thought 'twas a lecherous Planet that goes to't with a Caudle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: How now Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: The Gentlemans horses are set up Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: No, no, no, we'll away.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: We'll away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: How? by my faith, but you shall not yet, by your leave; where's Bess? call your Mistress Sir, to welcome these kinde Gentlemen my friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Overd. How Bess, Peg?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Plain Bess! I know how the world goes then, he has been a bed with Bess, y'faith; there's no trust to these Widows; a yong horsing Gentle∣man carries 'em away clear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Now where's your Mistress Sir, how chance she comes not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Sir, she requests you to excuse her for a while, she's busie with a Millener about Gloves.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Gloves?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath▪
SP.P: Hoyda, Gloves too!

LG.L: Could she finde no other time to chuse
Gloves, but now when my friends are here?

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: No Sir, 'tis no matter, we thank you for your good will Sir; to say truth, We have no busi∣ness with her at all at this time, y'faith Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: O that's another matter; yet stay, stay Gentlemen and taste a cup of Wine ere you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Overd.
SP.P: No, thank you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Mr Pepperton, Mr Weatherwise will you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I'll see the Wine in a drunkards shooes first, and drink't after he has brew'd it; but let her go, she's fitted y'faith; a proud surly Sir here, he domineers already; one that will shake her bones, and go to Dice with her money, or I have no skill in a Kalender: Life! he that can be so saucy to call her Bess already, will call her Prating-Queen a moneth hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: They have given thee all the slip.

LG.L: So a fair riddance!
There's three rubs gone, I've a clear way to th' Mi∣stress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: You'd need have a clear way, because y'are a bad pricker.

LG.L: Yet if my Bowl take bank, I shall go nigh
To make my self a saver:
Here's Alley room enough, I'll try my fortune,
I am to begin the world like a yonger Brother;
I know that a bold face, and a good spirit,
Is all the Joynture he can make Widow;
And't shall go hard, but I'll be as rich as he, or at least seem so; and that's wealth enough:
For nothing kills a Widow's heart so much,
As a faint bashful wooer, though he have thousands,
And come with a poor Water-gruel spirit,
And a Fish▪ market face, he shall ne'r speed:
I would not have himself left a poor Widower.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Faith I'm glad I'm alive; to commend thee Kate, I shall be sure now to see my commenda∣tions delivered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I'll put her to't y'faith.

LG.L: But soft ye Kate,
How and she should accept of your bold kindness?
A cheif point to be thought on, by my faith;
Marry therefore Sir, be you sure to step in, for fear I should shame my self, and spoil all:

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Well, I'll save your credit then for once, but look you come there no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Away, I hear her coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: I am vanish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: How does my life, my soul, my dear sweet Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I have wrong'd your patience, made you stand too long here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: There's no such thing y'faith Madam; y'are pleas'd to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Yes, I confess I was too slow Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Why you shall make me amends for that then, with a quickness in your Bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: That were a speedy mends Sir.

LG.L: Why then you are out of my debt;
I'll cross the Book, and turn over a new leaf with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: So with paying a small debt, I may chance run into a greater.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: My faith your credit will be the better then: There's many a brave gallant would be glad of such fortune, and pay use for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P:
Some of them have nothing else to do;
they would be idle and 'twere not for interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I promise you Widow, were I a setter up, such is my opinion of your payment, I durst trust you with all the ware in my shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I thank you for your good will, I can have no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Not of me y'faith, nor that neither; and you know all—Come make but short service Widow, a kiss and to bed, I'm very hungry y'faith Wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What are you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Oh a yonger Brother has an excellent stomack, Madam, worth a hundred of your sons and heirs, that stay their wedding stomacks with a hot bit of a Common Mistress, and then come to a Wid∣ows bed like a flash of lightning: Y'are sure of the first of me, not of the five hundreth of them. I ne∣ver took Physick yet in my life; you shall have the Doctor continually with them, or some bottle for his Deputy: Out flies your moneys for restoratives and strengthnings, in me 'tis sav'd in your purse, and found in your children; they'll get peevish Pothecaries stuff, you may weigh 'em by th' ounces; I boys of War, brave Commanders, that shall bear a bredth in their shoulders, and a weight in their hips, and run over a whole Countrey with a pound a Beef, and a Bisket in their Belly. Ho Widow, my kisses are Vir∣gins, my embraces perfect, my strength solid, my love constant, my heat comfortable; but to come to the point, inutterable.

LG.L: But soft ye, soft ye; because you stand so stricly
Upon your purity, I'll put you to't Sir.
Will you swear here, you never yet knew woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Never, as man ere knew her; By this Light, Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What, what Sir! shrew my heart he moves me much,

LG.L: Nay, since you love to bring a man on's knees,
I take into the same oath, thus much more,
That y'are the first Widow, or Maid, or Wife,
That ever I in suit of love did Court,
Or honestly did woo: How say you to that Widow?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Marry I say Sir, you had a good portion of Chastity left you, though ill fortune run away with the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: That I kept for thee Widow; she's of fortune, and all her strait bodied daughters; thou shalt have't Widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Push what do you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I cannot bestow't better.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I'll call my Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: By my troth you shall not Madam▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Does your worship call Sir?

LG.L: Ha pox! are you peeping? Throws somewhat at him.
He came in a good time, I thank him for't:

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What do you think of me? your very for∣ward Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Extremity of love.

LG.L: You say y'are ignorant,
It should not seem so surely by your play;
For ought I see, you may make one your self,
You need not hold the Cards to any Gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: That love should teach men ways to wrong it self!
