LG.L: Are these the first-fruits of your boldness Sir?
If all take after these, you may boast on 'em;
There comes few such to Market among women:
Time you were taken down Sir▪
I've lost my way again, there's but two paths that leads to Widows beds,
That's wealth or forwardness, and I've took the wrong one.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: He marry my Lady! why there's no such thought yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Oh here they are all again too!

LG.L: Are you come Gentlemen?
I wish no better men.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Oh the Moon's chang'd now!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: See you that Gentleman yonder!

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Yes sweet Madam.

LG.L: Then pray be witness all of you, with this kiss
I chuse him for my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: A pox on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: And with this parted Gold that two hearts joyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Never with chaster love then this of mine.

LG.L: And those that have the hearts to come to th'wedding,
They shall be welcome for their former loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: No, I thank you, y'ave choak'd me al∣ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I never suspected mine Almanack till now; I believe he plays cogging John with me, I bought it at his shop; it may learn the more knavery by that.

LG.L: Now indeed Gentlemen I can bid you welcome,
Before 'twas but a flourish.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Nay so my Almanack told me There should be an Eclipse, but not visible in our Horizon, but about the Western inhabitants of Mexi∣cana and Califormia.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Well, we have no business there Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Nor we have none here Sir, and so fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: You save the house a good labor Gen∣tlemen; the fool carries them away in a Voider. Where be these fellows?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serv.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Here Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serv.
SP.P: What your worship pleasure.

LG.L: Oh, this is something like, take you your ease Sir,
Here are those now more fit to be commanded:

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: How few women are of thy minde; she thinks it too much to keep me in subjection for one day, whereas some wives would be glad to keep their husbands in aw all days of their lives, and think it the best bargain that ere they made.

LG.L: I'll spare no cost for th'wedding, some device too,
To show our thankfulness to Wit and Fortune;
It shall be so—Run streight for one o'th' wits:

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: How! one o'th' wits? I care not if I run on that account; are they in Town think you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Whether runst thou now?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: To an Ordnary for one of the wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Why to an Ordnary, above a Tavern.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: No, I hold your best wits to be at Ordnary, nothing so good in a Tavern:

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: And why I pray Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow:
SP.P: Because those that go to an Ordnary dine better for Twelve pence, then he that goes to a Ta∣vern for his five shillings; and I think those have the best wits that can save four shillings, and fare better too:

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: So Sir, all your wit then runs upon Victuals.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: 'Tis a sign 'twill hold out the longer then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: What were you saying to me?

LG.L: Please your worship,
I heard there came a Schollar over lately
With old Sir Oliver's Lady.
Is she come?
What is that Lady?
A good Gentlewoman,
Has been long prisoner with the enemy.
I know't too well, and joy in her re∣lease.
Go to that house then straight, and in one labor
You may bid them, and entreat home that Schollar:

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serv.
SP.P: It shall be done with speed Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I'll along with you
And see what face that Schollar has brought over; a thin pair of Barbreaking Sea-water Green∣chops, I warrant you.

LG.L: Since wit has pleasur'd me, I'll pleasure wit,
Schollars shall fare the better.—O my Blessing▪
I feel a hand of mercy lift me up
Out of a world of waters, and now sets me
Upon a Mountain, where the Sun plays most,
To chear my heart ev'n as it dries my limbs.
What deep I see beneath me? in whose falls
Many a nimble mortal toyls,
And scarce can feed himself; the streams of Fortune
'Gainst which he tugs in vain, still beat him down,
And will not suffer him (past hand to mouth)
To lift his arm to his Posterities Blessing.
I see a careful sweat run in a ring
About his Temples, but all will not do:
For till some happy means relieve his state,
There he must stick, and bide the wrath of fate▪
I see this wrath upon an uphil Land,
O blest are they can see their falls, and stand!
How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: With much entreating Sir, he's come.

LG.L: Sir y'are—my Brother!—Joys come thick together:
Sir when I see a Schollar, pardon me,
I am so taken with affliction for him,
That I must run into his arms, and claspe him▪
Art stands in need Sir of such cherishers,
I meet too few; 'twere a brave world for Schollars
If half a Kingdom were but of your minde Sir;
Let Ignorance and Hell confound the rest.
Let it suffer sweet Sir, you cannot think
How deerly you are welcome.
May I live
To show you service for't.
Your love your love Sir,
We go no higher, nor shall you go lower.
Sir I'm bold to send for you, to request
A kindness from your wit, for some device
To grace our wedding it shall be worth your pains;
And something more 'express my love to art,
You shall not receive all in bare embracements.
Your love I thank, but pray Sir pardon me,
I've a heart says I must not grant you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: No, what's your reason Sir?

LG.L: I'm not at peace
With the Lady of this house; now you'll excuse me,
Sh'as wrong'd my sister, and I may not do't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: The Widow knows you not.

LG.L: I never saw her face to my remembrance.
Oh that my heart should feel her wrongs so much,
And yet live ignorant of the injurer!
Let me perswade thee, since she knows you not,
Make clear the weather, let not griefs betray you,
I'll tell her y're a worthy friend of mine,
And so I tell her true; thou art indeed.
Sir here she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What are you busie Sir?

LG.L: Nothing less Lady; here's a Gentleman
Of noble parts, beside his friendship to me;
Pray give him liberal welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: He's most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low▪
SP.P: The vertues of his minde will deserve largely.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Methinks his outward parts deserve as much then; a proper Gentleman it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Come worthy Sir.

LG.L: I follow; check thy blood
For fear it prove too bold to wrong thy goodness▪
A wiseman makes affections but his slaves.
Break 'em in time, let 'em not master thee.
O 'tis my sisters enemy, think of that!
Some speedy grief fall down upon the fire,
Before it take my heart; let it not rise
'Gainst brotherly Nature, Judgment, and these wrongs;—make clear the weather.
Oh who could look upon her face in storms!
Yet pains may work it out, griefs do but strive
To kill this sparke, I'll keep it still alive.

DIV3.HEAD: Scaen 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter the three late Suiters, Weatherwise, Pepperton, and Overdon▪ joyn'd with Sir Gilbert Lambston▪

LG.L: FAith Sir Gilbert, forget and forgive,
There's all our hands to a new bargain of friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: I and all our hearts to boot, Sir Gil∣bert.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Why la you! there's but four Suitors left on's in all th'world, and the fifth has the Widow; if we should not be kinde to one another, and so few on's y'faith, I would we were all rak'd up in some hole or other.

LG.L: Pardon me Gentlemen, I cannot but remember
Your late disgraceful words before the Widow,
In time of my oppression.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Puh, Saturn raign'd then, a melancholy grumbling Planet, he was in the third house of privy enemies, and would have bewray'd all our plots; be∣side there was a fiery conjunction in the Dragons tails, that spoil'd all that ere we went about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Dragon or Devil, somewhat 'twas I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Why I tell you Sir Gilbert, we were all out of our wits in't; I was so mad at that time my self. I could have wish'd an hind-quarter of my Bull out of your belly again, whereas now I care not if you had eat tail and all; I am no niggard in the way of friendship, I was ever yet at Full Moon in good fellowship, and so you shall finde, if you look into the Almanack of my true nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Well all's forgiven for once, hands a∣pace, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Ye shall have two of mine to do you a kindness,—yet when they're both abroad, who shall look to th' house here?

SP.SPEAKER: Pep. Overd.
SP.P: Not onely a new friendship, but a friend.

LG.L: But upon this condition Gentlemen
You shall hear now a thing worth your revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: And you doubt that,
You shall have mine before-hand, I've one ready, I never go without a black Oath about me.

LG.L: I know the least touch of a spur in this
Will now put your desires to a false gallop,
By all means slandrous in every place,
And in all companies, to disgrace the Widow,
No matter in what rank, so it be spightful
And worthy your revenges; so now I,
It shall be all my study, care, and pains,
And we can lose no labor; all her foes
Will make such use on't, that they'll snatch it from us
Faster then we can forge it; though we keep
Four tongues at work upon't and never cease.
Then for the indifferent world, faith they're apter
To bid a slave welcome, then a truth;
We have the odds of our side: this in time
May grow so general, as disgrace will spred,
That wilde dissention may divide the bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Pep. Excellent!

SP.SPEAKER: Overd.
SP.P: A pure revenge, I see no dregs in't.

LG.L: Let each man look to his part now, and not feed
Upon one dish all four on's, like plain Maltmen;
For at this feast we must have several kickshaws,
And delicate made dishes, that the world
May see it is a Banquet finely furnish'd.
Why then let me alone for one of your kickshaws.
I have thought on that already.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Prethee how Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Marry Sir I'll give it out abroad, that I have lain with the Widow my self, as 'tis the fashion of many a gallant to disgrace his new Mistress, when he cannot have his will of her, and lie with her name in every Tavern, though he ne'r came within a yard of her person; so I being a Gentleman, may say as much in that kinde as a gallant; I am as free by my Fathers copy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: This will do excellent Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: And moreover I'll give the world thus much to understand beside that, if I had not lain with the Widow in the wain of the Moon, at one of my Seven Stars houses, when Venus was about busi∣ness of her own, and could give no attendance, she had been brought a bed with two roaring boys by this time, and the Gemini being Infants, I'd have made away with them like a step-mother, and put mine own boys in their places.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Why this is beyond talk, you out-run your Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Whoop! draw home next time; here are all the old shooters, that have lost the game at pricks? what a fair mark had Sir Gilbert on't, if he had shot home before the last Arrow came in? methinks these show to me now, for all the world, like so many lousie beggars turn'd out of my Ladies Barn, and have ne'r a hole to put their heads in.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Mass here's her Ladiships Ass, he tells us any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Ho Pickadille!

LG.L: What Sir Gilbert Lambston!
Gentlemen, Out-laws all, how do you do?
How! what do'st call us? how goes the world at home Lad?
What strange news?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: This is the state of prodigals as right as can be, when they have spent all their means on brave feasts, their glad to scrape to a serving-man for a meals meat.

LG.L: So you that whilome like four prodigal rivals,
Could Goose or Capon, Crane or Woodcock chuse,
Now're glad to make up a poor meal with news;
A lamentable hearing!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: He's in passion;—up to the Eyebrows for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: O Mr Weatherwise, I blame none but you;—you are a Gentleman deeply read in Ponds Al∣manack;—methinks you should not be such a shal∣low fellow; you knew this day the twelf of June would come when the Sun enters into the Crabs room, and all your hopes would go aside, aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P:
The fool says true y'faith Gentlemen, I
knew 'twould come all to this pass, I'll show't you presently.

LG.L: If you had spar'd but four of your twelve Signs now,
You might have gone to a Tavern and made merry with 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: H'as the best Moral meaning of an Ass, that ere I heard speak with tongue: Look you here Gentlemen; fifth day neither Fish nor Flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: No, nor good Red-herring, and you look again.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Sixth day privily prevented.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Marry faugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Seventh day shrunk in the wetting.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Nay, so will the best Ware bought for love or money.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The eighth day over head and ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: By my faith he come home in a sweet pickle then!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The ninth day, scarce sound at heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: What a pox ail'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The tenth day a Courtiers welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: That's a cup of Bear, and you can get it.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The eleventh day, stones against the wind.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Pox of an Ass, he might have thrown 'em better.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Now the twelf day Gentlemen, that was our day.—Past all redemption.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Then the Devil go with't.

LG.L: Now you see plainly Gentlemen how we're us'd,
The Kalender will not lie for no mans pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Push, y'are too confident in Almanack Posies.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Faith so said we.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb:
SP.P: They're meer delusions.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: How!—You see how knavishly they happen Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: I, that's because they're foolishly bely'd Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Well, take your courses Gentlemen with∣out 'em, and see what will come on't▪ you may wan∣der like masterless-men, there's ne'r a Planet will are a half-penny for you: If they look after you I'll be hang'd, when you scorn to bestow two pence to look after them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: How! a device at the wedding say'st thou!

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Why? have none of you heard of that yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: 'Tis the first news y'faith Lad.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Oh there's a brave travelling Schollar en∣tertain'd into the house a purpose; one that has been all the world over, and some part of Jerusalem; h'as his Chamber, his dyet, and three Candles allow'd him after Supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: By my faith he need not complain for victuals then, what ere he be.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: He lies in one of the best Chambers i'th' house, bravely matted; and to warm his wits as much, a cup of Sack and an Aqua Vitae Bottle stands just at his elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: He's shroudly hurt by my faith; if he catch an Ague of that fashion, I'll be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: He'll come abroad anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Art sure on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Why he ne'r stays a quarter of an hour in the house together:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb▪
SP.P: No; how can he study then?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Pha best of all; he talks as he goes, and writes as he runs, besides you know 'tis death to a traveller to stand long in one place.

LG.L: It may hit right boys!—Honest Pick∣adille
Thou wast wont to love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I'd good cause Sir then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Thou shalt have the same still, take that.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Will you believe me now; I ne'r lov'd you better in my life, then I do at this present.

LG.L: Tell me now truly; who are the Pre∣senters?
What Parsons are employed in the Device?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Parsons! not any Sir; my Mistress will not be at the charge; she keeps none but an old Welsh Vicar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Prethee, I mean, who be the Speakers?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Troth I know none, but those that open their mouths: Here he comes now himself, you may ask him.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath▪
SP.P: Is this he? by my faith one may pick a Gentleman out of his Calves, and a Schollar out on's Cheeks; one may see by his looks what's in him; I warrant you there has ne'r a new Almanack come out these douzen years, but he has studied it over and over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Do not reveal us now.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Because you shall be sure on't, you have gi∣ven me a nine-pence here, and I'll give you the slip for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Well said; now the Fool's pleas'd, we may be bold.

LG.L: Love is as great an enemy to Wit,
As Ignorance to Art; I finde my powers
So much employ'd in business of my heart,
That all the time's too little to dispatch
Affairs within me.—Fortune too remiss
I suffer for thy slowness, had I come
Before a Vow had chain'd their souls together,
There might have been some hope, though ne'r so little:
Now there's no spark at all, nor ere can be,
But dreadful ones struck from Adultery;
And if my Lust were smothered with her will,
Oh who could wrong a Gentleman so kinde,
A stranger made up with a Brothers minde?
Peace, peace, enough, let me alone to manage it.
A quick invention, and a happy one
Reward your study Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Gentlemen I thank you.

LG.L: We understand your wits are in em∣ployment Sir,
In honor of this wedding.
Sir, the Gentleman
To whom that worthy Lady is betroth'd,
Vouchsafes t'accept the power of my good will in't▪
I pray resolve us then Sir, for we're friends
That love and honor her.
Whether your number be yet full, or no,
Of those which you make choice of for Presenters.
First, 'tis so brief, because the time is so,
We shall not trouble many; and for those
We shall employ, the house will yeild in servants▪
Nay then under your leave and favor Sir,
Since all your pains will be so weakly grac'd,
And wanting due performance lose their lustre;
Here are four of us Gentlemen, her friends▪
Both lovers of her honor, and your Art,
That would be glad so to express our selves,
And think our service well, and worthily plac'd.
My thanks do me no grace for this large kindness,
You make my labors proud of such Presenters.
She shall not think Sir, she's so ill be∣lov'd,
But friends can quickly make that number perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: She's bound t'acknowledge it.

LG.L: Onely thus much Sir,
Which will amaze her most; I'd hav't so carried,
As you can do't, that neither she, nor none
Should know what friends we were till all were done.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I that would make the sport.

LG.L: I like it well Sir;
My hand and faith amongst you Gentlemen,
It shall be so disposed of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: We are the men then.

LG.L: Then look you Gentlemen, the Device is single,
Naked, and plain, because the time's so short,
And gives no freedom to a wealthier sport;
'Tis onely Gentlemen, the four Elements
In liveliest forms, Earth, Water, Air, and Fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Mass and here's four of us too.

LG.L: It fits well Sir.
This the effect, That whereas all those four
Maintain a natural opposition
And untruc'd war, the one against the other,
To shame their ancient Envies they should see
How well in two brests all these do agree:

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: That's in the Bride and Bridegroom; I am quick Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: In faith it's pritty Sir, I approve it well.

LG.L: But see how soon my happiness, and your kindness
Is crost together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Crost! I hope not so Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev:
SP.P: I can employ but two of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: How comes that Sir?

LG.L: Air and the Fire should be by me presented,
But the two other in the forms of women.
Nay, then we're gone again: I think these women
Were made to vex and trouble us in all shapes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: Faith Sir you stand too nicely.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: So think I Sir.

LG.L: Yet when we tax our selves, it may the better
Set off our Errors, when the fine eyes judge 'em;
But water certainly should be a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: By my faith then he is gelded since I saw him last; he was thought to be a man once, when he got his wife with childe before he was married.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Fie, you are fishing in an other stream Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: But now I come to yours, and you go to that Sir; I see no reason then but Fire and Water should change shapes and genders.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: How prove you that Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Why there's no reason but Water should be a man, because Fire is commonly known to be a Quean.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: So Sir, you argue well.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Nay more Sir, Water will break in at a lit∣tle crevice, so will a man if he be not kept out; Wa∣ter will undermine▪ so will an Informer; Water will ebb and flow, so will a Gentleman; Water will search any place, and so will a Constable, as lately he did at my Seven Stars for a yong Wench that was stole; Water will quench Fire, and so will Wat the Barber▪ Ergo, Let Water wear a Codpeece-point.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Faith Gentlemen I like your company well.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath
SP.P: Let's see who'll dispute with me at the Full o'th' Moon▪

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: No Sir; and you be vain glorious of your Talent, I'll put you to't once more.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I'm for you Sir, as long as the Moon keeps in this quarter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Well, how answer you this then? Earth and Water are both bearers; therefore they should be women.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath:
SP.P: Why so are Porters and Pedlers, and yet they are known to be men.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I'll give you over in time Sir, I shall repent the bestowing on't else.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: If I that have proceeded in five and twenty such Books of Astronomy, should not be a∣ble to put down a Schollar now in One thousand six hundred thirty and eight, the Dominical Letter be∣ing G, I stood for a Goose.

LG.L: Then this will satisfie you though that be a woman;
Oceanus, the Sea, that's chief of Waters,
He wears the form of a man, and so may you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Now I hear reason, and I may consent.

LG.L: And so, though Earth challenge a Femi∣nine face▪
The matter of which Earth consists, that's dust,
The general soul of Earth is of both kindes.
Fit your selves Gentlemen, I've enough for me.
Earth, Water, Air, and Fire, part 'em amongst you▪

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Let me play fair, I was my Fathers eldest son.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I but this Air never possest the Lands▪

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: I'm but dispos'd to jest with you Sir; 'tis the same my Almanack speaks on, is't not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: That 'tis Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Then leave it to my discretion, to fit both the part and the person.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: You shall have your desire Sir.

LG.L: We'll agree
Without your trouble now Sir, we're not factious,
Or envy one another for best parts;
Like quarrelling Actors that have passionate fits,
We submit always to the Writers wits.
He that commends you, may do't liberally,
For you deserve as much as praise can show.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: We'll send to you privately.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I'll dispatch you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: We'll poyson your device.

LG.L: She must have pleasures,
Shows and conceits, and we disgraceful doom.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: We'll make your Elements come limping home.

LG.L: How happy am I in this unlook'd for grace,
This voluntary kindness from these Gentlemen!
'Twill set off all my labors far more pleasing
Before the Widow, whom my heart calls Mistress,
But my tongue dares not second it.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs Lowwater and her Man-husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: How say you now Kate?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I like this Musick well Sir▪

LG.L: O unfortunate!
Yet though a Tree be guarded from my touch,
There's none can hinder me to love the fruit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Nay, now we know your minde Bro∣ther, we'll provide for you.

LG.L: O were it but as free as late times knew it▪
I would deserve, it all lifes wealth could do it.

DIV3.HEAD: Scaen 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter at Sir Oliver's house, himself, old Sunset, his redeemed Lady, Master Sandfield, the Dutch Merchant, Philip Sir Oliver's Son, and Savorwit alooff off, and Servants.

LG.L: O My reviving joy! thy quickning pre∣sence
Makes the sad night of threescore and ten years
Sit like a youthful Spring upon my blood:
I cannot make thy welcome rich enough
With all the wealth of words.
It is exprest Sir
With more then can be equal'd; the ill store
Lies onely on my side, my thanks are poor.
Blest be the goodness of his minde for ever,
That did redeem thy life, may it return
Upon his fortunes double! that worthy Gentleman,
Kinde Mr Beveril! showre upon him, Heaven,
Some unexpected happiness to requite him!
For that my joys unlook'd for;—O more kinde,
And juster far is a meer strangers goodness
Then the sophistick faith of natural sons.
Here's one could juggle with me, take up the ransom,
He and his loose companion.
Say you me so Sir?
I'll eat hard Eggs for that tick:
Spend the money▪
And bring me home false news, and empty pockets:
In that yong gallants tongue there you were dead▪
Ten weeks before this day, had not this Merchant
Brought first the truth in words, your self in sub∣stance.
Pray let me stay you here, ere you proceed Sir;
Did he report me dead say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Else you live not.

LG.L: See now Sir, you may lay your blame too rashly,
When no body look'd after it; let me tell you Sir,
A Fathers anger should take great advice,
Ere it condemn flesh of so dear a price.
He's no way guilty yet for that report
The general tongue of all the Countrey spred;
For being remov'd 'far off, I was thought dead.
Can my faith now be taken into favor Sir?
Is't worthy to be trusted?

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: No by my troth is't not; 'twould make shift to spend another ransom yet.

LG.L: Well Sir, I must confess y'ave here dealt well with me;
And what is good in you, I love again.
Now am I half ways in, just to the girdle,
But the worst part's behinde.
Marry I fear me Sir,
This weather is too glorious to hold long.
I see no cloud to interpose it Sir,
If you place confidence in what I have told you.
Nay 'tis clear skie on that side, would 'twere so
All over his obedience; I see that,
And so does this good Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth,
SP.P: Do you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: That makes his honesty doubtful.

LG.L: I pray speak Sir,
The truth of your last kindness makes me bold with you.
The Knight your husband, Madam, can best speak▪
He trulest can show griefs whose heart they break.
I'm sorry yet for more, pray let me know't Sir,
That I may help to chide him, though 'twould grieve me.
Why then prepare for't; you came over now
In the best time to do't you could pick out:
Not onely spent my money, but to blinde me,
He and his wicked Instrument

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Now he fiddles me

LG.L: Brings home a Minion here, by great chance known;
Told me she was his sister, she proyes none.
This was unkindly done Sir; now I'm sorry
My good opinion lost it self upon you;
You are not the same son I left behinde me,
More grace took him.—O let me end in time,
For fear I should forget my self, and chide him!
Where is he Sir? though he beguil'd your eyes,
He cannot deceive mine; we're now too hard for him.
For since our first unfortunate separation.
I've often seen the Girl (would that were true)
By many a happy accident, many a one;
But never durst acknowledge her for mine own,
And therein stood my joys distrest again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: You rehearse miseries wife! call the Maid down.

LG.L: She's been too often down to be now called so;
She'll lie down shortly, and call some body up.
He's now to deal with one Sir that knows truth;
He must be sham'd or quit, there's no mean saves him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I hear her come.

LG.L: You see how hard 'tis now
To redeem good opinion being once gone;
Be careful then, and keep it when 'tis won.
Now see me take a poyson with great joy,
Which but for thy sake, I should swoun to touch.
What new affliction? am I set to sale
For any one that bids most shame for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Look you? do you see what stuff they've brought me home here?

LG.L: Oh bless her eternal powers! my life, my comforts,
My nine years grief, but everlasting joy now!
Thrice welcome to my heart; 'tis she indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I'm unfit to carry a ransom.

LG.L: Down on your knees to save your Belly harmless;
Ask blessing, though you never mean to use it,
But give't away presently to a Beggar-wench:

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My faith is blemish'd, I'm no man of trust Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Rise with a Mothers blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: All this while sh'as rise with a sons.

LG.L: But soft ye, soft ye wife!
I pray take heed you place your blessing right now.
This honest Dutchman here told me he saw her
At Antwerp in an Inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: True, she was so Sir.

LG.L: Sir, 'tis my quality; what I speak once,
I affirm ever; in that Inn I saw her,
That lets her not to be your daughter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Oh Sir, is't come to that!

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: Here's joys ne'r dreamt on!

LG.L: O Mr Sunset, I am at the rising
Of my refulgent happiness! now son Sandfield,
Once more and ever!

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: I am proud on't Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Pardon me boy, I have wrong'd thy faith too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Now may I leave my shell, and peep my head forth.

LG.L: Where is this Savorwit, that honest whore∣son?
That I may take my curse from his knaves shoulders.
O Sir, I feel you at my very blade here,
Your curse is ten stone weight, and a pound over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Come, thou'rt a witty Varlet, and a trusty.

LG.L: You shall still finde me a poor faithful fel∣low Sir,
If you have another ransome to send over,
Or daughter to finde out.
I'll do thee right boy;
I ne'r yet knew thee but speak honest English,
Marry in Dutch I found thee a knave lately.
That was to hold you but in play a little,
Till farther truths came over, and I strong;
You shall ne'r finde me a knave in mine own tongue▪
I have more grace in me, I go out of England
Still when I take such courses; that shows modesty Sir.
Any thing full of wit, and void of harm,
I give thee pardon for, so was that now.
Faith now I'm quit, I finde my self the nim∣bler
To serve you so again, and my will's good▪
Like one that lately shook off his old Irons,
And cuts a purse at Bench, to deserve new ones.
Since it holds all the way so fortunate still,
And strikes so even with my first belief,
This is the Gentleman wife, yong Mr Sandfield here,
A man of worthy parts beside his Lands,
Whom I make choice of for my daughters Bed▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: But he'll make choice there of another Bed∣fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I wish 'em both the happiness of love Sir.

LG.L: 'Twas spoke like a good Lady—
And your memory can reach it wife; but 'tis so long ago too.
Old Mr Sunset he had a yong daughter
When you unluckily left England so,
And much about the age of our Girl there;
For both were nurs'd together.
'Tis so fresh
In my remembrance, now y'have wakned it,
As if twelve years were but a twelve hours dream.
That Girl is now a proper Gentlewoman,
As fine a body wife, as ere was measured
With an Indenture cut in farthing steaks.
O say not so Sir Oliver, you shall pardon me Sir.
Y'faith Sir you are too blame.
Sings, dances, plays,
Touches an Instrument with a Motherly Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: 'Tis your own daughter that you mean that by.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: There's open Dutch indeed, and he could take it▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: This wench under your leave▪

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: You have my love in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Is my sons wife that shall be.

LG.L: Thus I'd hold with't;
Is your sons wife that should be Mr Sandfields?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I come in happy time to a feast of marri∣ages.

LG.L: And now you put's i'th' minde, the hour draws on
At the new married Widows there we're look'd for;
There will be entertainments, sports, and banquets;
There these yong lovers shall clap hands together,
The seed of one feast shall bring forth another.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: Well said Sir Oliver.

LG.L: Y'are a stranger Sir,
Your welcome will be best.

SP.SPEAKER: Dutch M.
SP.P: Good Sir excuse me:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: You shall along y'faith, you must not re∣fuse me.

DIV3.STAGE: Manent Mother, Sister, Philip, and Savorwit.

LG.L: O Mother! these new joys that sets my soul up,
Which had no means, nor any hope of any,
Has brought me now so far in debt to you,
I know not which way to begin to thank you▪
I am so lost in all, I cannot ghess
Which of the two my service most constrains,
Your last kinde goodness, or your first deer pains.
Love is a Mothers duty to a son,
As a sons duty is both love and fear.
I ow you a poor life Madam, that's all;
Pray call for't when you please, it shall be ready for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Make much on't Sir till then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: If Butter'd Sack will—

LG.L: Me thinks the more I look upon her son,
The more thy sisters face runs in my minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Belike she's somewhat like her—It makes the better Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Was Antwerp, say you, the first place you found her in?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil
SP.P: Yes Madam: Why do you ask?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Whose daughter were you?

SP.SPEAKER: Grace▪
SP.P: I know not rightly whose, to speak truth Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: The Mother of her was a good twigger the whilst.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: No: with whom were you brought up then?

LG.L: With those Madam▪
To whom ('ve often heard) the enemy sold me.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: What's that?

LG.L: Too often have I heard this piteous story
Of a distressed Mother I had once▪
Whose comfortable sight I lost at Sea▪
But then the years of childhood took from me
Both the remembrance of her, and the sorrows.
Oh I begin to feel her in my blood!
My heart leaps to be at her;—What was that Mo∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: Some said an English Lady;—But I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: What's thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: Grace.

LG.L: May it be so in Heaven,
For thou art mine on Earth; welcome dear childe
Unto thy Fathers house, thy Mothers arms,
After thy forein sorrows.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: 'Twill prove gallant!

LG.L: What son! such earnest work—I bring thee joy now
Will make the rest show nothing, 'tis so glorious.
Why 'tis not possible, Madam, that mans happiness
Should take a greater height then mine aspires.
No, now you shall confess it, this shall quit thee
From all fears present, or hereafter doubts
About this business—

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Give me that sweet Mother.

LG.L: Here take her then, and set thine arms a work,
There needs no 'fection, 'tis indeed thy sister:

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Cuds me, I feel the razor!

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Why, how now son? how comes a change so soon?

LG.L: Oh, I beseech you Mother, wound me any where,
But where you pointed last: That's present death.
Devise some other miserable torment,
Though ne'r so pittiless, and I'll run and meet it.
Some way more merciful let your goodness think on▪
May steal away my joys, but save my soul;
I'll willingly restore back every one
Upon that milde condition any thing
But what you spake last, will be comfortable.
Y'are troubled with strange fits in England here▪
Your first suit to me did entreat me hardly,
To say 'twas she, to have old wrath appeas'd;
And now 'tis known your sister, y'are not pleas'd▪
How should I show my self!

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Say 'tis not she.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth▪
SP.P: Shall I deny my daughter?

LG.L: O you kill me,
Beyond all tortures!

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Why do you deal thus with me!

LG.L: She is my wife, I married her at Antwerp;
I have known the way unto her Bed these three moneths.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: And that's too much by twelve weeks for a sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I understand you now, too soon, too plain.

LG.L: O Mother▪ if you love my peace for ever,
Examine her again, finde me not guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: 'Tis now too late, her words make that too true.

LG.L: Her words! shall bare words overthrow a soul?
A body is not cast away so lightly.
How can you know 'tis she? let Sense decide it,
She then so yong, and both so long divided.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: She tells me the sad story.

LG.L: Does that throw me?
Many a distress may have the face of yours,
Tha never was kin to you.
But however Sir,
I trust you are not married.
Here's the witness,
And all the wealth I had with her; this Ring
That joyn'd our hearts together.
Oh too clear now!
Thou brought in evidence to o'rthrow thy self,
Had no one word been spoke onely this shown
T'had been enough to approv'd her for mine own;
See here two Letters that begun my name,
Before I knew thy Father this I gave her,
And as a Jewel fastned to her ear.
Pardon me Mother▪ that you finde it stray,
I kept it till I gave my heart away.
Oh to what Mountain shall I take my flight,
To hide the monster of my sin from sight!
I'll to Wales presently, there's the best Hills
To hide a poor knave in.
Oh heap not desperation upon guilt!
Repent yet, and all's sav'd; 'twas but hard chance;
Amongst all sins, Heaven pities ignorance,
She's still the first that has her pardon sign'd,
All sins else see their faults, she's onely blinde.
Go to thy Chamber, pray, leave off▪ and win,
One hours repentance cures a twelve moneths sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: O my distressed husband, my dear Brother!

LG.L: O Savorwit! never came sorrow yet
To mankinde like it; I'm so far distrest,
I've no time left to give my heart attendance,
Too little all to wait upon my soul!
Before this empest came, how well I stood,
Full in the beams of blessedness and joy!
The memory of man, could never say
So black a storm fell in so bright a day:
I am that man that ev'n life surfeits of;
Or if to live, unworthy to be seen
By the savage eye-sight, give's thy hand;
Commend me to thy prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav
SP.P: Next time I say 'em

LG.L: Farewel my honest brest, that cravest no more
Then possible kindness, that I've found thee large in,
And I must ask no more; there Wit must stay,
It cannot pass, where Fate stops up the way.
Joy thrive with thee; I'll never see thee more.
What's that Sir! pray come back, and bring those words with you,
You shall not carry 'em so out of my company:
There's no last refuge, when your Father knows it;
There's no such need on't yet, stay but till then,
And take one with you that will imitate you
In all the desperate On-sets man dare think on.
Were it to challenge all the Wolves in France,
To meet at one set battel, I'ld be your half in't.
All Beasts of Venome,—what you had a minde to,
Your part should be took still: For such a day
Let's keep our selves in heart, then am I for you.
In the mean time to beat off all suspition,
Let's to the Bridehouse too—here's my Petition.
Thou hast a learning art when all hopes flie;
Let one night waste, there's time enough left to die.
A minute's as good as a thousand year Sir,
To pnk a mans heart like a Summer suit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter two or three Servants placing things in order, with Pickadille the Clown like an Overseer.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Bestir your bones nimbly, you Ponderous Beef-buttock'd Knaves; what a number of lazy Hindes do I keep company withal? where's the flesh∣colour Velvet Cushion now, for my Ladies Pease∣porridge-tawny Sattin-bum? you attendants upon Revels!

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serv
SP.P: You can prate and domineer well, because you have a priviledge place; but I'd fain see you set your hand to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: O base bone-pickers, I set my hand to't! when did you ere see a Gentleman set his hand to any thing, unless it were to a sheep-skin, and receive a hundred pound for his pains.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serv.
SP.P: And afterward lie in the Counter for his pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Why true, Sir, 'tis for his pleasure indeed; for spight of all their teeths, he may lie i'th' Hole when he list.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serv.
SP.P: Marry and should for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I, thou wouldst make as good a Baud as the best Jailor of them all; I know that.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serv.
SP.P: How? Fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Hark! I must call you Knave within, 'tis but staying somewhat the longer for't.

DIV3.STAGE: Loud Mufick. Enter the new married Widow, and Kate her Husband, both changed in Apparel, Arm in arm together; after them Sir Oliver Twilight, Mr Sunset, and the Dutch Merchant; after them the Mother, Grace the daughter sad, with Jane Sunset; after these, melancholy Philip, Savorwit, and Mr Sand∣field.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: This fair Assembly is most freely wel∣come.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Sir Ol Thanks to you good Sir.

LG.L: Come my long wisht for Madam,
You and this worthy stranger take best welcome,
Your freedom is a second feast to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: How is't with my brother?

LG.L: The fit holds him still;
Nay, Love's more violent.
'Lass poor Gentleman! I would he had my office without money;
If he should offer any, I'd refuse it.
I have the Letter ready:
He's worthy of a place that knows how to use it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: That's well said,—Come Ladies, Gentlemen; Sir Oliver, good, seat your selves; shall we be found unreadiest?—What is you Gentleman with the Funeral-face there? me thinks that look does ill become a Bride-house?

LG.L: Who does your worship mean Sir? my son Philip?
I am sure he had ne'r less reason to be sad:
Why are you sad son Philip?
How Sir, sad!
You shall not finde it so Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav:
SP.P: Take heed he do not then—You must be∣ware how you carry your face in this company; as far as I can see, that yong Bridegroom has Hauks-eyes, he'll go nigh to spell sister in your face, if your Nose were but crooked enough to serve for an S. he'd finde an eye presently, and then he has more light for the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I'll learn then to dissemble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Nay and you be to learn that now, you'll ne'r sit in a Brancht Velvet-gown as long as you live; you should have took that at Nurse, before your Mother wean'd you; so do all those that prove great children, and batten well: Peace, here comes a Schol∣lar indeed, he has learnt it I warrant you.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr Beveril with a Pastboord.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Kinde Sir, your welcome, you take all the pains Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I wish they were but worthy of the grace Of your fair presence, and this choice Assembly. Here is an abstract, Madam, of what's shown, Which I commend to your Favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Thank you for't Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I would I durst present my love as boldly:

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: My honest Brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Look thee here Sweet-heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: What's there sweet Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Musick, and we're ready.

STAGE.P:
A Thing like a Globe opens of one side o'th' Stage, and flashes out Fire, then Sir Gilbert that pre∣sents the part, issues forth with Yellow-hair and Beard, intermingled with stroaks like wilde flames, a three
forked Fire in's hand; and at the same time Air comes down, hanging by a cloud, with a Coat made like an Almanack, all the Twelve Moons set in it, and the Four Quarters, Winter, Spring, Summer, and Au∣tumn, with change of Weathers, Rain, Lightning, and Tempest, &c.

And from under the Stage at both ends, arises Wa∣ter and Earth, two persons; Water with green flags upon his head, standing up instead of hair; and a Beard of the same, with a Chain of Pearl. Earth with a number of little things like Trees, like a thick Grove upon his head, and a wedg of Gold in his hand, his Gar∣ment of a Clay colour.
The Fire speaking first, the Schollar stands behinde, give's him the first word, which he now fol∣lows.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: The Flame of Zeal—

LG.L: The wicked Fire of Lust▪
Does now spred heat through Water, Air, and Dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: How? he's out in the beginning—The Wheel of Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: The Devil set Fire o'th' Distaff.

LG.L: I that was wont in elder times to pass
For a bright Angel, so they cal'd me then,
Now so corrupted with the upstart Fires
Of Avarice, Luxury, and Inconstant heats,
Struck from the bloods of cunning Clap-aln Daugh∣ters,
Night-walking Wives, but most libidinous Widows,
That I that purifie ev'n Gold it self,
Have the contemptible Dross thrown in my face,
And my bright name walk common in disgrace.
How am I us'd alate, that I am so handled,
Thrust into Alleys, Hospitals, and Tubs!
I was once a name of comfort, warm'd great houses
When Charity was Landlord, I have given welcome
To forty Russet Yeomen at a time,
In a fair Christmas-Hall. How am I chang'd!
The Chimneys are swept up, the Hearth as cold
As the Fore-fathers Charity in the Sun.
All the good hospitable heat now turns
To my yong Landlords Lust, and there it burns.
Rich Widows that were wont to chuse by Gravity
Their second Husbands, not by tricks of Blood,
Are now so taken with lose Aretine Flames
Of nimble wantonness, and high-fed Pride,
They marry now but the third part of Husbands,
Boys, smooth fac'd Katamites, to fulfil their Bed,
As if a woman should a woman wed.
These are the Fires alate, my brightness darks,
And fills the world so full of beggerly Sparks,

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Heat! how am I disgrac'd? what rogue should this be?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: By my faith Monsieur Fire, y'are a hot whore∣son.

LG.L: I fear my Brother is beside his wits,
He would not be so senseless to rail thus else.
After this heat, you Madams, fat and fair,
Open your Casements wide, and take in Air;
But not that Air false women make up oaths with.
No, nor that Air gallants perfume their cloaths with;
I am that Air that keeps about the Clouds,
None of my Kinred was smelt out in Crouds,
Not any of our house was ever tainted,
When many a thousand of our foes have fainted.
Yet some there are that be my cheif poluters,
Widows that falsifie their Faith to Suiters,
And will give fair words when the Signs in Cancer▪
But at the next remove a scurvy answer,
Come to the poor mens houses, eat their Banquet,
And at night, with a Boy tost in a Blanquet.
Nay, shall I come more near? Perhaps at noon,
For here I finde a spot full in the Moon.
I know youths trick, what's she that can withstand it,
When Mercury raigns, my Ladies Chamber Planet?
He that believes a Widows words shall fail,
When Venus Gown-skirts sweeps the Dragons tail.
Fair weather the first day she makes to any,
The second cloudy, and the third day rainy;
The fourth day a great storm, Lightning, and Thun∣der;
A Bolt strikes the Suitor, a Boy keeps her under.
Life! these are some counterfeit slaves crept in their rooms,
A purpose for disgrace: they shall all share with me.
Heart! who the Devil should these be?
My faith Gentlemen,
Air has perfum'd the room well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: So me thinks, Madam.

LG.L: A man may smell her meaning two rooms off,
Though his Nose wanted Reparations,
And the Bridge left at Shoreditch as a Pledge
For Rosa Solace, in a Bleaking-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Life! what should be his meaning in't?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: I wonder.

LG.L: Me thinks this room should yet retain such heat,
Struck out from the first Ardor, and so glow yet,
You should desire my company, wsh for Water▪
That offers here to serve your several Pipes,
Without constriant of Mill, or death of Water∣house.
What if I sprinkled on the Widows Cheeks
A few cool drops to ly the guilty heat,
That flshes from her Conscience to her face;
Would't not refresh her shame? From such as she
I first took weakness and inconstancy;
I sometimes swell above my banks and spred;
They're commonly with childe, before they're wed:
In me the Syrens sing before they play,
In her more witchcraft, for her smiles betray;
Where I'm lest seen, there my most danger lies,
So in those parts hid most from a mans eyes:
Her heart, her love, or what may be more close,
I know no mercy, she thinks that no loss:
In her poor gallants, Pirats thrive in me;
I help to cast away, and so does she.
Nay, and you can hold nothing sweet Sir Water,
I'll wash my hands a'you, ever hereafter.
Earth stands for a Full-point, me you should hire
To stop the gaps of Water, Air and Fire;
I love muck well, but your first husband better.
Above his soul he lov'd it as his end
Did fearfully witness it; at his last gasp
His spirit flm'd, as it forsook his Brest,
And left the sparkles quarrelling 'bout his Lips:
Now of such Mettal the Devil makes him Whips.
He shall have Gold enough to glut his Soul;
And as for Earth, I'll stop his Cranes-throat full.
The wealth he left behinde him, most men know,
He wrung inconscionably from the rights
Of poor mens livings, he drunk dry their brows.
That Liquor has a curse, yet nothing sweeter;
When your posterity drinks, then 'twill taste bit∣ter.
And now to vex, 'gainst Nature, Form, Rule, Place,
See once four waiting Elements all embrace.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter four at several corners, addrest like the four Winds, with Wings, &c. and dance all to the Drum and Fiff; the four Elements seem to give back, and stand in amaze; the South wind has a great red face, the North wind a pale bleak one, the Western wind one cheek red, and another white, and so the Eastern wind; at the end of the dance, the Winds shove off the disguises of the other four, which seem to yeeld and almost fall off of themselves at the coming of the Winds; so all the four old Suiters are discovered. Exeunt all the Winds but one, which is the Schollar in that disguise, so shows all.

LG.L: How? Sir Gilbert Lambston, Mr Overdon,
All our old Suiters! you have took pains my Masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: We made a vow we'd speak our mindes to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: And I think we're as good as our words, though it cost some of our purses; I ow money for the Clouds yet, I care not who knows it; the Planets are sufficient enough to pay the Painter, and I were dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Who are you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Your most unworthy servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Pardon me, is't you Sir?

LG.L: My disgrace urg'd my wit to take some form,
Wherein I might both best and properliest
Discover my abusers, and your own,
And show you some content, before y'had none.
Sir, I ow much both to your care and love,
And you shall finde your full requital worthy.
Was this the plot now your poor envy works out?
I do revenge my self with pittying on you:
Take Fire into the Buttery, he has most need on't,
Give Water some small Beer, too good for him;
Air, you may walk abroad like a Fortune-teller,
But take down Earth, and make him drink i'th' Cel∣ler.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: The best revenge that could be.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I commend you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I thought they were some such sneakers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: The four Suiters! and here was a mess of mad Elements.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Lights, more lights there; where be these Blew-coats?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: You know your lodgings Gentlemen to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: 'Tis bounty makes bold guests, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid
SP.P: Good rest Lady.

LG.L: A most contentful night, begin a health Madam
To your long joys, and may the years go round with't—
As many thanks as you have wisht 'em hours Sir,
Take to your lodging with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: A general rest to all.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I'm excepted.

LG.L: Take in another to you then, there's room enough.
In that exception, faith to serve us both.
The Dial of my sleep goes by your eyes.

DIV3.HEAD: Scaen 1.

LG.L: NOw like a greedy Usurer alone,
I sum up all the wealth this day has brought me;
And thus I hug it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Prethee!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Thus I kiss it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I can't abide these kissings.

LG.L: How Sir? not?
I'll try that sure, I'll kiss you out of that humor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Push, by my troth I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What cannot you Sir?

LG.L: Not toy, nor bill and imitate House-Pigeons,
A married man must think of other matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: How, other matters Sir! what other mat∣ters?

LG.L: Why are there no other matters that belong to't?
Do you think y'have married onely a Cock-sparrow?
And fit but for one business, like a fool;
You shall not finde it so.
You can talk strangely Sir,
Come, will you to bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: No faith will not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What not to bed Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: And I do, hang me; not to bed with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: How not to bed with me! Sir with whom else?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Why am not I enough to lie with my self?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Is that the end of marriage?

LG.L: No by my faith—'tis but the begin∣ning, yet death is the end on't,
Unless some trick come i'th' middle and dash all.
Were you so forward lately, and so youth∣ful,
That scarce my modest strength could save me from you,
And are you now so cold?
I've thought on't since,
It was but a rude part in me y'faith
To offer such bold tricks to any woman,
And by degrees I shall well break my self from't;
I feel my self well chastned since that time,
And not the third part now so loosely minded.
O when one sees their follies, 'tis a comfort;
My very thoughts take more staid years upon 'em.
Oh marriage is such a serious divine thing,
It makes youth grave, and sweetly nips the Spring.
If I had chose a Gentleman for care
And worldly business, I had ne'r took you;
I had the offers of enough, more fit
For such employment; I chose you for love;
Youth, and content of heart, and not for troubles:
You are not ripe for them; after y'have spent
Some twenty years in dalliance, youths affairs,
Then take a Book in your hand, and sum up cares;
As for wealth now, you know that's got to your hands.
But had I known't had been so wrong∣fully got,
As I heard since, you should have had free leave
To have made choice of another Master for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Why, can that trouble you?

LG.L: It may too soon; but go,
My sleeps are sound, I love not to be started
With an ill conscience at the fall of midnight,
And have mine eyes torn ope with poor mens curses,
I do not like the fate on't, 'tis still apt
To breed unrest, dissention, wilde debate,
And I'm the worst at quarrels upon Earth,
Unless a mighty injury should provoke me.
Get you to bed, go.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Not without you in troth Sir.

LG.L: If you could think how much you wrong your self
In my opinion of you, you would leave me now
With all the speed you might; I like you worse
For this fond heat, and drink in more suspition of you.
You high-fed Widows are too cunning people
For a poor Gentleman to come simply to.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What's that Sir?

LG.L: You may make a youth on him,
'Tis at your courtesie, and that's ill trusted:
You could not want a friend, beside a Suiter,
To sit in your husbands gown, and look over your writings.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What's this?

LG.L: I say there is a time when women
Can do too much, and understand too little.
Once more to bed, I'd willingly be a Father
To no more Noses then I got my self;
And so good night to you.
Now I see the infection,
A yellow poyson runs through the sweet Spring
Of his fair youth already, 'tis distracted;
Jealous of that which Thought yet never acted.
O dear Sir! on my knees I swear to thee.
I prethee use them in thy private Chamber,
As a good Lady should, spare 'em not there,
'Twill do thee good, faith none 'twill do thee here
Have I yet married poverty, and must love;
What Fortune has my heart? that's all I crav'd,
And that lies now a dying; it has took
A speeding poyson, and I'm ignorant; how!
I never knew what beggery was, till now:
My wealth yeelds me no comfort in this plight,
Had want but brought me love, I'd happen'd right.
So, this will serve now for a prepara∣tive
To ope the powers of some dislike at first;
The Physick will pay't home.—How dost thou Sir?
How goes the work?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Your Brother has the Letter.

LG.L: I finde no stop in't then, it moves well hitherto,
Did you convey it closely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: He ne'r set eye of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: I cannot read too often.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Peace, to your office—

LG.L: What blessed fate took pitty of my heart,
But with her presence to relieve me thus!
All the large volumes that my time hath master'd,
Are not so precious to adorn my spirit,
As these few lines are to inrich my minde.
I thirst again to drink of the same Fountain—

LETTER.P: I found your care and love so much in the performance of a little, wherein your wit and art had late employment, that I dare now trust your bosome with business of more weight and eminence: Little thought the world, that since the Wedding dinner, all my mirth was but dissembled, and seeming joys but counterfeit. The truth to you Sir is, I finde so little signs of content in the bagain I made i'th' morning, that I began to repent before Evening Prayer, and to shew some fruits of his wilful neglect, and wilde disposition, more then the day could bring forth to me, has now for∣sook my Bed, I know no cause for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: But I'll besworn I do:

LETTER.P: Being thus distrest Sir, I desire your comfort∣able presence and councel, whom I know to be of worth, and judgment; that a Lady may safely impart her griefs to you, and commit 'em to the Vertues of Com∣miseration, and Secrecy.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your unfortunate Friend The Widow Wife.

LG.L: I have took order for your private admittance
With a trusty servant of mine own, whom I have
Plac'd at my Chamber-door to attend your coming,
He shall not wait too long▪ and curse my slowness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: I would you'd come away then.

LG.L: How much am I beguil'd in that yong Gen∣tleman!
I would have sworn had been the perfect abstract
Of honesty and mildness: 'Tis not so—
I pardon you sweet Brother, there's no hold
Of what you speak now, you're in Cupids pound.
Blest be the secret hand that brought thee hither;
But the dear hand that writ it, ten times blest.
That's I still, has blest me now ten times at twice.
Away I hear him coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Strike it sure now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: I warrant thee sweet Kate, chuse your best—

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Who's there?

LG.L: O Sir, is't you! y'are welcome then,
My Lady still expects you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Who's with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: Not any creature living Sir.

LG.L: Drink that,
I've made thee wait too long.
It does not seem so now Sir. Sir if a man
Tread warily as any wise man will,
How often may he come to a Ladies Chamber, and be welcome to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Thou giv'st me learned councel for a Closet.

LG.L: Make use on't Sir, and you shall finde no loss in't.
So, you are surely in, and you must under.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Kate with all the Guests, Sir Oliver, Mr Sunset, Wife, Daughter, Philip, Sandfield, and Savorwit.

LG.L: Pardon my rude disturbance, my wrongs urge it,
I did but try the plainness of her minde,
Suspecting she dealt cunningly with my youth,
And told her the first night, I would not know her;
But minding to return, I found the door
Warded suspitiously, and I heard a noise;
Such as fear makes, and guiltiness at th'approaching
Of an unlook'd for husband.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: This is strange Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Behold its bard, I must not be kept out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: There is no reason Sir.

LG.L: I'll be resolv'd in't.
If you be sons of honor, follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Then must I stay behinde, for I think I was begot i'th' Woodyard, and that makes every thing go so hard with me.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter confusedly with the Widow, and her Brother the Schollar.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: That's he, be sure on him▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Be not so furious Sir.

LG.L: She whispered to him to slip into her Closet.
What have I taken you? is not my dream true now?
Unmerciful Adulteress, the first night!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Nay good Sir patience.

LG.L: Give me the Villains heart,
That I may throw't into her bosom quick,
There let the Letcher pant.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Nay sweet Sir.

LG.L: Pardon me,
His life's too little for me.
How am I wrongfully sham'd? speak your intent Sir
Before this company, I pursue no pity▪
This is a fine theevish juggling, Gentle∣men!
She asks her mate that shares in guilt with her? Too gross, too gross!

SP.SPEAKER: Bev.
SP.P: Rash mischeif.

LG.L: Treacherous Sir!
Did I for this cast a friends arm about thee?
Gave thee the welcome of a worthy spirit,
And lodg'd thee in my house, nay, entertain'd thee
More like a natural Brother, then a stranger;
And have I this reward? Perhaps the pride
Of thy good parts, did lift thee to this impudence?
Let her make much on 'em, she gets none of me.
Because thou'rt deeply read in most Books else,
Thou wouldst be so in mine; there it stands for thee,
Turn ore the leaves, and where you left, go forward.
To me it shall be like the Book of Fate,
Ever claspt up.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: O dear Sir, say not so.

LG.L: Nay I'll swear more; for ever I refuse her,
I'll never set a foot into her bed;
Never perform the duty of man to her,
So long as I have breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: What an oath was there Sir? call't again.

LG.L: I knew by amorous sparks struck from their eyes,
The fire would appear shortly in a blaze;
And now it flames indeed:—Out of my house,
And take your Gentleman of good parts along with you;
That shall be all your substance;
He can live in any Emperors Court in Christendom▪
You know what you did Wench, when you chose him
To thrust out me; you have no politick love,
You are to learn to make your market; you,
You can chuse wit, a burden light and free,
And leave the grosser Element with me.
Wealth, foolish trash, I thank you, out of my doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Nay good Sir, hear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth. Suns.
SP.P: Sweet Sir.

LG.L: Pray to your Chambers Gentlemen, I should be here
Master of what is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Hear her but speak Sir?

LG.L: What can she speak but womans com∣mon language?
She's sorry and asham'd for't that helps nothing;
Sir, since it is the hard hap of my life
To receive injury where I plac'd my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Why la, I told you what escapes she'd have.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Nay pray Sir hear her forward.

LG.L: Let our parting be full as charitable as our meeting was,
That the pale envious world, glad of the food
Of others miseries, civil dissentions,
And nuptial strifes, may not feed fat with ours.
But since you are resolv'd so wilfully
To leave my Bed, and ever to refuse me,
As by your rage I finde it your desire,
(Though all my actions deserve nothing less)
Here are our friends, men both of worth and wis∣dom,
Place so much power in them, to make an evenness
Between my peace and yours: All my wealth within doors
In Gold and Jewels, lie in those two Caskets
I lately led you to; the value of which
Amounts to some five thousand a peece;
Exchange a charitable hand with me,
And take one Casket freely, fare thee well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: How say you to that now?

LG.L: Troth I thank her Sir!
Are not both mine already?—You shall wrong me,
And then make satisfaction with mine own;
I cannot blame you; a good course for you—
I know 'twas not my luck to be so happy;
My miseries are no starters when they come,
Stick longer by me.
Nay, but give me leave Sir,
The wealth comes all by her.
So does the shame,
Yet that's most mine; why should not that be too?
Sweet Sir, let us rule so much with you,
Since you intend an obstinate separation,
Both from her Bed and boord, give your consent
To some agreement reasonable and honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Must I deal honestly with her Lust?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Nay good Sir.

LG.L: Why I tell you all the wealth her hus∣band left her,
Is not of power to purchase the dear peace
My heart has lost in these adulterous Seas;
Yet let her works be base, mine shall be noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: That's the best word of comfort I heard yet.

LG.L: Friends may do much.—Go, bring those Caskets forth,
I hate her sight, I'll leave her, though I lose by't.
Spoke like a Noble Gentleman y'faith;
I'll honor thee for this—
O cursed man!
Must thy rash heat force this division?
You shall have free leave now, without all fear;
You shall not need oyl'd hinges, privy passages,
Watchings, and whisperings; take him boldly to you.
O that I had that freedom, since my shame
Puts by all other fortunes, and owns him.
A worthy Gentleman, if this cloud were past him,
I'd marry him, wer't but to spight thee onely,
So much I hate thee now.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servants with two Caskets, and the Suiters.

LG.L: Here come the Caskets Sir, hold your good minde now,
And we shall make a vertuous end between you.
Though nothing less she merit but a curse,
That might still hang upon her, and consume her still;
As t'has been many a better womans fortune
That has deserv'd less vengeance, and felt more;
Yet my minde scorns to leave her shame so poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Nobly spoke still.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: This strikes me into Musick, Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Parting of goods before the bodies joyn?

SP.SPEAKER: Weath▪
SP.P: This 'tis to marry beardless domineering Boys: I knew 'twould come to this pass; well fare a just Almanack yet; for now is Mercury going into the second house near unto Ursa major, that great Huncks, the Bear at the Bridge foot in Heaven; which shows horrible Bear-baitings in wedlock; and the Sun nere entring into th'Dog, sets 'em all together by th'ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: You see what's in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I think 'tis as I left it.

LG.L: Then do but gage your faith to this assem∣bly.
That you will nere return more to molest me,
But rest in all revenges full appeas'd,
And am ply satisfied with that half my wealth,
And take't as freely as life wishes health.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: La you Sir; come, come, faith you shall swear that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Nay Gentlemen for your sakes, now I'll deal fairly with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I would we might see that Sir.

LG.L: I could set her free,
But now I think on't, she deserves it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: Nay do not check your goodness, pray Sir, on with't.

LG.L: I could release her, ere I parted with her;
But 'twere a curtesie ill plac'd, and set her
At as free liberty to marry again,
As you all know she was before I knew her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: What couldst thou Sir?

LG.L: But 'tis too good a blessing for her.
Up with the Casket Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: O Sir stay!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I have nothing to say to you.

LG.L: Do you hear Sir?
Pray let's have one word more with you for our money.
Since y'have expos'd me to all shame and sor∣row,
And made me fit but for one hope and fortune,
Bearing my former comforts away with you
Show me a parting charity but in this,
For all my losses pay me with that freedom,
And I shall think this treasure as well given
As ever 'twas ill got▪
I might afford it you,
Because I never mean to be more troubled with you.
But how shall I be sure of the honest use on't,
How you'll employ that liberty? perhaps sinfully,
In wantonness unlawful, and I answer for't.
So I may live a Baud to your loose works still,
In giving 'em first vent; not I, 'shall pardon me,
I'll see you honestly joyn'd, ere I release you;
I will not trust you for the last trick you plaid me; here's your old Suiters.

SP.SPEAKER: Peppert.
SP.P: Now, we thank you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: My Almanack warns me from all Cuckold∣ly Conjunctions.

LG.L: Be but commander of your word now Sir,
And before all these Gentlemen, our Friends,
I'll make a worthy choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: Flie not ye back now.

LG.L: I'll try thee once. I am married to an∣other,
There's thy release.
Hoyda! there's a release with a witness?
Thou'rt free sweet wench.
Married to another!
Then in revenge to thee,
To vex thine eyes 'cause thou hast mock'd my heart,
And with such treachery repaid my love;
This is the Gentleman I embrace and chuse▪
O torment to my blood, mine enemy!
None else to make thy choice of, but the man
From whence my shame took head!
'Tis done to quit thee;
Thou that wrong'st womans love, her hate can fit thee.
Brave wench y'faith! now thou hast an honest Gentleman,
Rid of a swaggering knave, and there's an end on't.
A man of good parts, this t'other had nothing!
Life, married to another?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gilb.
SP.P: O brave rascal with two wives!

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Nay and our women be such subtil Ani∣mals, I'll say wait at the Carriers for a Countrey Chamber-maid, and live still a Batchelor: When Wives are like Almanacks, we may have every year a new one, then I'll bestow my money on 'em; in the mean time I'll give 'em over, and ne'r trouble my Almanack about 'em.

LG.L: I come in a good time to see you hang'd Sir,
And that's my comfort.—Now I'll tickle you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: You make me laugh indeed.

LG.L: Sir you remember
How cunningly you choak'd me at the Banquet
With a fine bandy Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Your own fist Sir.

LG.L: I'll read the Statute-Book to you now for't:
Turn to the Act in Anno Iac primo,
There lies a Halter for your Wind-pipe:

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: Fie no.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Faith but you'll finde it so Sir, an't be fol∣lowed.

LG.L: So says my Almanack, and he's a true man.
Look you; the thirteenth day work for the Hang∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: The fourteenth day, make haste, 'tis time you were there then.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: How? is the Book so sancy to tell me so?

LG.L: Sir I must tell you now, but without Call,
The Law would hang you, if married to another:
You can but put me to my Book, sweet Brother.
And I've my Neck-verse perfect, here and here.
Heaven give thee eternal joy, my dear sweet Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Who's here?

LG.L: O Devil, her self? did she betray me.
A pox of shame, nine Coaches shall not stay me
I've two such deep healths in two joys to pledge,
Heaven keep me from a surfeit:
Mistress Low water!
Is she the jealous Cuckold, all this quoils about?
And my right worshipful Serving-man, is it you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Low.
SP.P: A poor wrong'd Gentleman, glad to serve for his own Sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: By my faith y'have serv'd the Widow a fine trick between you.

LG.L: No more my enemy now, my Brothers wife,
And my kinde Sister.
There's no starting now from't:
'Tis her own Brother, did not you know that?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: 'Twas never told me yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I thought you'd known't.

LG.L: What matter is't, 'tis the same man was chose still,
No worse now then he was, I'm bound to love you,
Y'have examin'd in this a double charity,
Which to your praise, shall to all times be known,
Advanc'd my Brother, and restor'd mine own,
Nay, somewhat for my wrongs, like a good sister,
For well you know the tedious suit did cost,
Much pains and fees, I thank you, 'tis not lost:
You wish'd for love, and faith I have bestow'd you
Upon a Gentleman that does deerly love you.
That recompence I've made you; and you must think Madam
I lov'd you well, (though I could never ease you)
When I fetcht in my Brother thus to please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol
SP.P: Here's unity for ever strangely wrought.

LG.L: I see too late there is a heavy judgment
Keeps company with Extortion, and foul deeds;
And like a wind which Vengeance has in chase,
Drives back the wrongs into the Injurers face.
My punishment is gentle, and to shew
My thankful minde for't, thus I'll revenge this,
With an embracement here, and here a kiss.
Why now the Bells they go trim, they go trim;
I wish'd thee Sir some unexpected blessing
For my Wives ransom, and 'tis faln upon thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath
SP.P: A pox of this, my Almanack ne'r gull'd me till this hour, the thirteenth day work for the hang∣man, and there's nothing toward it; I'd been a fine ass, if I'd given twelve-pence for a horse to have rid to Tyburn to morrow.—But now I see the error, 'tis false figured, it should be thirteen days and a half, work for the hangman; for he ne'r works under thir∣teen-pence half-penny:—Beside, Venus being a spot in the ns garment, shows there should be a woman found in Hose and Doublet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Nay faith sweet wife, we'll make no more hours on't now, 'tis as fine a contracting time, as ever came amongst Gentle-folks. Son Philip, Master Sandfield, come to the book here:

LG.L: Now I'm wak'd
Into a thousand miseries and their torments.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: And I come after you Sir, drawn with wilde horses; there will be a brave show on's anon, if this weather continue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Come wenches; where be these yong Gen∣mens hands now?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Poor Gentleman my son, some other time Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I'll have't now y'faith wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: What are you making here?

LG.L: I have sworn, sweet Madam,
My son shall marry Mr Sunsets daughter,
And Mr Sandfield mine.
So you go well Sir,
But what make you this way then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: This! for my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: O back Sir, back! this is no way for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns. Sir Ol.
SP.P: How?

LG.L: O let me break an oath, to save two souls,
Lest I should wake another judgment greater;
You come not here for him Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: What's the matter?

LG.L: Either give me free leave to make this match,
Or I'll forbid the Banes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Good Madam take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Here Mr Sandfield then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Cuds Bodkins!

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Take you this Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sandf.
SP.P: You could not please me better, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Hoyda! is this your hot love to my daughter Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: Come hither Philip, here's a wife for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Zunes, he shall ne'r do that, marry his Sister!

LG.L: Had he been rul'd by you, he had married her.
But now he marries Mr Sunsets daughter,
And Mr Sandfield yours, I've sav'd your oath Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: O may this blessing hold!

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: Or else all the liquor runs out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: What Riddle's this Madam?

LG.L: A Riddle of some fourteen years of age now.
You can remember Madam, that your daughter
Was put to nurse to Mr Sunsets wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: True! that we talk'd on lately.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I grant that Madam.

LG.L: Then you shall grant what follows: At that time
You likewise know old Mr Sunset here
Grew backward in the world, till his last fortunes
Rais'd him to this estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: Still this we know too.

LG.L: His wife then Nurse, both to her own and yours,
And both so yong, of equal years, and daughters;
Fearing the extremity of her fortunes then,
Should fall upon her Infant; to prevent it,
She chang'd the children, kept your daughter with her,
And sent her own to you for better fortunes:
So long enjoyn'd by solemn oath unto't,
Upon her death bed, I have conceal'd this,
But now so urg'd here's yours, and this is his.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav
SP.P: Hoop! the joy is come of our side.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: Hay. I'll cast mine Almanack to the Moon too and strike out a new one for next year.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: It wants expression, this miraculous blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sav
SP.P: Me thinks I could spring up, and knock my hea against yon Slver-feeling now for joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Weath.
SP.P: By my faith, but I do not mean to follow you there, so I may dash out my Brains against Charls Wain, and come down as wise as a Carman▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ol.
SP.P: I never wondred yet with greater pleasure.

LG.L: What tears have I bestow'd on a lost daughter,
And left her behinde me.
This is Grace,
This Jane: Now each has her right name and place.

SP.SPEAKER: Suns.
SP.P: I never heard of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Wid.
SP.P: I'll swear you did not Sir.

LG.L: How well I have kept mine oath against my will;
Clap hands, and joy go with you.—Well said Boys!

SP.SPEAKER: Phil▪
SP.P: How art thou blest from shame, and I from ruine:

SP.SPEAKER: Sav.
SP.P: I, from the Bakers Ditch, if I'd seen you in.

LG.L: Not possible the whole world to match again,
Such grief, such joy, in minutes lost and won.
Who ever knew more happiness in less com∣pass?
Ne'r was poor Gentleman so bound to a Sister,
As I am, for the weakness of thy minde;
Not onely that thy due, but all our wealth
Shall lie as open as the Sun to man,
For thy employments; so the charity
Of this dear Bosom bids me tell thee now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Low.
SP.P: I am her servant for't.

LG.L: Hah worthy Sister!
The government of all, I bless thee with.
Come Gentlemen, on all perpetual Friend∣ship.
Heaven still relieves, what Misery would destroy,
Never was night yet of more general Joy.
NOw let me see what weather shall we have now;
Hold fair now, and I care not.—Mass Full Moon too,
Just between five and six this Afternoon:
This happens right, the skie for the best part clear,
Save here and there a Cloud or two dispers'd
That's some dozen of Panders, and half a score Pick-Pockets,
You may know them by their whistle,
And they do well to use that while they may:
For Tyburn craks the Pipe, and spoils the Musick.
What says the destiny of the hour this Evening,
Hah, fear no colours by my troth agreed then,
The red and white looks chearfully: For know ye all,
The Planet's Jupiter, you should be jovial;
There's nothing lets it, but the Sun i'th' Dog;
Some bark in corners that will fawn and cog.
Glad of my fragments for their Ember-week,
The Signs in Gemini too, both hands should meet;
There should be noise i'th' Air, if all things hap,
Though I love Thunder, when you make the clap.
Some faults perhaps have slipt, I am to answer;
And if in any thing, your revenge appears,
Send me in, with all your fists about mine ears.

DIV1.HEAD: Courteous Reader, these Books following are printed for Humphrey Moseley, at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard.

DIV2.HEAD: Various Histories, with curious Discourses in humane Learning, &c.
DIV2.P: 1 HIstoricall relations of the united Provinces of Flanders, by Cardinall Bentivoglio: Englished by the Right Honorable Henry Earle of Monmouth. Fol.

2. The History of the Warrs of Flanders, written in Italian by that learned and famous Cardinal Bentivo∣glio; Englished by the Right Honorable Henry E. of Monmouth. The whole worke Illustrated with a Map of the 17. Provinces, and above 20 Figures of the chiefe Personages mentioned in this History. Fol.

3. The History of the Warrs of the Emperor Justi∣nian, with the Persians, Goths, and Vandalls, written in Greek by Procopius of Caesaria in eight Bookes, trans∣lated into English by Sir Henry Holcroft. Knight. Fol.
